Yet it is there we learn to dance.
We dread the shifting tide,
Yet it carries us to shores we need to find.

As long as we remain unsettled,
Hope blooms like wildflowers after fire—
Not in spite of displacement,
But because of it.

SETTLED DUST

They dream of stillness, these restless souls,
Of foundations that never crack or sway.
They speak of roots while eyeing distant hills,
Of anchors while charting stars.

People wish to be settled—
A comforting lie we tell ourselves
As we pack and unpack our questions,
As we wander rooms of our own making.

But hope lives in the spaces between certainties,
In the fault lines of what we thought we knew.
It thrives in the soil we've yet to tame,
In the wilderness beyond our walls.

Only as long as they are unsettled
Do they see with unclouded eyes.
Only in the vertigo of change
Do they reach for what might be possible.

So let the dust never settle too long.
Let the questions remain unanswered.
For in that sacred unsettling,
We find ourselves becoming.

UNSETTLED MERCY

We build our fortresses of habit,
Constructing walls of well-worn paths.
The settled life—a treasured prison
Where dreams collect like dust on shelves.

People wish to be settled, yes,
To know exactly what comes next.
To wake and sleep without surprise,
To age inside familiar lines.

Yet notice how the settled pond
Grows stagnant in its perfect peace,
While rivers, wild and wandering,
Carry life through changing lands.

Only as long as they are unsettled
Do humans stretch beyond themselves.
Only when maps prove insufficient
Do we chart territories unknown.

So bless the earthquake of your doubts.
Praise the storms that shake your house.
For hope dwells not in certainty
But in the courage to remain unsettled.

THE SETTLED PARADOX

We carve our names in stone
And call it permanence,
As if the mountains themselves
Weren't slowly turning to sand.

People wish to be settled—
A curious desire for creatures
Born of stardust and change,
Whose hearts beat in constant motion.

We chase stability like shadows,
Build routines like fortresses,
While inside our bones remember
The nomadic journey of our ancestors.

Only as long as they are unsettled
Can they see beyond the horizon.
Only in the quicksand of uncertainty
Do they learn to dance instead of sink.

Perhaps wisdom lies not in finding ground
But in loving the earthquake;
Not in claiming territory
But in becoming pilgrims again.

For hope is not the absence of trembling,
But the courage to tremble and still move forward.

SETTLERS AND SEEKERS

They plant their flags in familiar soil,
These settlers of the comfortable lands.
They mark their boundaries with certainty,
And call their knowledge complete.

People wish to be settled—
To silence the whispers of what if,
To quiet the call of the unmapped road,
To still the hunger for what lies beyond.

But notice how the settled eye grows blind
To miracles disguised as ordinary days.
Notice how the settled heart forgets to beat
With the wild rhythm of becoming.

Only as long as they are unsettled
Do questions bloom like spring flowers.
Only when foundations shift and crack
Can new light enter long-closed rooms.

So praise the blessed unsettling,
The sacred displacement of what we thought we knew.
For hope lives not in arrival
But in the courage to depart again and again.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People wish to be settled. Only as long as they are unsettled is there any hope for them.'

responses.text:
Settled Dust

In quiet corners of familiar rooms,
We build our nests of certainty and ease.
Fear whispers: "Stay where safety blooms,
Where life's wild tempests cannot seize."

But look—see how the settled dust
Grows thick upon our dreaming souls.
In comfort's cradle, dreams adjust,
Shrink smaller as our spirit folds.

It's in the stumbling and the fall,
The midnight questions without end,
The path unmarked, the stranger's call,
Where possibility transcends.

The unsettled heart beats loud and clear,
Awake to wonder, primed to see
The world anew when change draws near,
In chaos finds its liberty.

So bless the ground that shifts below,
The certainties that fall away.
For only in the letting go
Can hope illuminate our way.

The Comfort Trap

They build their houses on unyielding ground,
With walls so thick no whispers enter in.
They call it peace, this silence they have found,
This absence of the chaos and the din.

But roots that never stretch will never grow,
And minds unshaken seldom learn to bend.
The settled heart beats steady, sure, and slow,
Yet misses how the world might rearrange, transcend.

It's in the earthquake of assumptions failed,
The landslide of beliefs we thought were true,
The flooding of emotions long curtailed
That we discover what we might pursue.

Unsettled souls stand naked to the storm,
Their questions hanging raw against the night.
They shiver, yes, but feel themselves transform,
As hope ignites within—a fragile light.

So praise the wanderers who cannot rest,
The seekers never satisfied with found.
In their unease, humanity is blessed
With futures yet unmapped on broken ground.

Nomad's Prayer

Settlement, that gilded cage we build
With mortgage dreams and pension plans,
The future neatly filed and willed,
Horizon measured by our hands.

We hang our pictures on the walls
To prove that we have found our place.
We silence doubt whenever it calls,
And trade our wonder for embrace.

But hope—that wild and wayward seed—
Sprouts not in gardens neatly kept,
But in the cracks of broken creed,
Where certainty has wept.

The unsettled heart knows morning best,
Greets sunrise with expectant eyes.
While settled souls, in false arrest,
Miss stars that dance across their skies.

So let me be the question mark,
The pause between the certain words,
A traveler embracing dark,
My spirit flying with the birds.

Unsettled, yes—but truly free
To hope beyond what I can see.

Quicksand Salvation

We build our homes on quicksand dreams,
And call it wisdom when we sink.
The settled life is not what it seems—
A stagnant pool where souls cannot drink.

See how the trees with deepest roots
Once danced as seedlings in the wind,
How every creature that disputes
Its boundaries finds what lies within.

Hope dwells not in the answered prayer
But in the asking, raw and true.
Not in the knowledge we declare,
But in the searching we pursue.

The unsettled heart beats wild with life,
Blood rushing toward the unknown shore.
It finds its purpose in the strife,
In questions never asked before.

So when your ground begins to shift,
Don't curse the earth for moving on.
Embrace the chaos as a gift—
New constellations wait at dawn.

For only those who lose their way
Can find the paths they're meant to claim.

Settlers and Seekers

They tell us: Settle down, set roots, be still.
Find comfort in the known, the safe, the sure.
Build fences round your heart until
No wilder dreams can enter, raw and pure.

The settled life—a photograph in frame,
A story with its ending pre-composed.
Days passing by, predictably the same,
The wonder of existence decomposed.

But watch—the child who questions everything,
The artist breaking forms to find what's true,
The thinker whose ideas take sudden wing,
All unsettled souls with hope breaking through.

Perhaps we need the ground to sometimes quake,
Our careful maps to suddenly prove wrong,
Our deepest certainties to bend and break
For new and truer music to grow strong.

The paradox that wisdom understands:
In unsettled soil, hope plants its seeds.
In shifting sands, not solid lands,
We find the path that to becoming leads.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I walk alone, I think of you my love'

responses.text:
When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
Your silhouette dancing in the evening light.
The rustling leaves whisper your gentle name,
As memories cascade through time's tender flight.

Footsteps echo on the empty street,
Yet your presence fills the spaces between.
The world transforms with thoughts of you,
Painting colors where gray has been.

The moon above guides my solitary way,
Just as your love guides my beating heart.
Though miles may stretch between our souls,
In my mind, we're never truly apart.

When I walk alone, I'm never lonely,
For you inhabit every breath I take.
Your love, a compass pointing homeward,
A sacred promise we'll never break.

SOLITARY PATHWAYS

When I walk alone, I think of you my love
Foot after foot on cobblestones worn thin
The city hums a melody unknown
While memories of us play from within

Street lamps flicker like the stars we counted
On that blanket spread beneath the pines
Your laughter echoes through these empty alleys
A ghost of joy from sweeter times

I pass the café where we shared our secrets
The bench where first our fingers intertwined
Each landmark bears the weight of your absence
Each step reminds me what I've left behind

The distance grows like shadows at sunset
Yet somehow you walk beside me still
Invisible companion of my journey
A presence that no separation can kill

PHANTOM WALKS

When I walk alone, I think of you my love
How strange that solitude brings you so near
The crowded rooms where we once stood together
Now echo emptier than this path I wander here

The gravel crunches underneath my feet
Like the sound of your approaching steps
I turn sometimes, expecting your smile
Only to greet the wind's cool breath

The trees have witnessed our separating ways
Their branches reaching like my longing arms
I collect fallen leaves as I would memories
Preserving what remains of faded charms

Perhaps in some parallel dimension
You walk this very path and think of me
Two solitudes connected by invisible threads
Across the vast expanse of what cannot be

WALKING REVERIE

When I walk alone, I think of you my love
Not with sadness, but with quiet grace
The world transforms into our private gallery
Each scene a canvas where your touch I trace

The morning dew—your tears of gentle laughter
The birdsong—echoes of your melodic voice
The wildflowers nodding in the meadow
Remind me why you were my heart's first choice

I gather thoughts like pebbles from a riverbed
Smooth and polished by time's patient hand
Building monuments of cherished moments
On the shifting shores of memory's sand

And though our paths diverged at life's crossroads
I find you in the rhythm of my stride
For love transcends the boundaries of presence
You walk within me, not just by my side

SHADOWS AND LIGHT

When I walk alone, I think of you my love
As twilight paints the sky in shades of fire
Your absence weighs like gravity upon me
Yet lifts me too, like wings of pure desire

I count my heartbeats like a monk with prayer beads
Each pulse a testament to what endures
Beyond the fragile boundaries of flesh and bone
Beyond what time erases or obscures

The city sleeps around my restless wandering
Windows darkened save for scattered lights
Like constellations guiding sailors homeward
Through the vast and lonely sea of night

Perhaps somewhere you're walking too, remembering
The patterns we once traced in stars above
Two souls connected by invisible threads
When I walk alone, I think of you my love

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I walk alone, I think of you my love'

responses.text:
When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
Your smile like sunlight breaking through the clouds.
The whisper of your name upon the breeze,
The memory of your touch, gentle as dawn.

Solitary footsteps echo on the path,
Yet in this silence, you are everywhere.
In rustling leaves, in distant singing birds,
In shadows dancing on the forest floor.

The world transforms when filtered through your absence,
Ordinary things become extraordinary signs.
A flower blooming speaks your secret language,
The setting sun reminds me of your warmth.

Though miles may stretch between our beating hearts,
In loneliness, I find you most complete.
For in these quiet moments of reflection,
Your spirit walks beside me, ever sweet.

SOLITARY PATHWAYS

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
Beneath the endless canvas of the sky.
Each footfall marks a rhythm of remembrance,
A percussion of the heart that cannot lie.

The city streets transform to sacred ground,
Where once we wandered, fingers intertwined.
Now phantom echoes of your laughter sound
In corners where your absence is defined.

I gather fragments of our history,
Collecting them like shells along the shore.
Each memory a treasure, incomplete,
Yet precious in the longing it restores.

The world feels different viewed through solitude,
More vibrant somehow, yet impossibly still.
As if your presence lingers in the air,
A ghost of joy that time cannot fulfill.

So I walk on, alone yet not alone,
Carrying you within each step I take.

PHANTOM COMPANION

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
The phantom weight of your hand still in mine.
The streets we never crossed together bloom
With possibilities of what might be.

I see you in the faces of the crowd,
A fleeting glimpse that makes my heart contract.
A stranger's laugh that mirrors yours so well
It stops me cold amid the city's rush.

The coffee shop where we have never sat
Becomes a shrine to conversations missed.
I order what I think you might have loved
And taste your absence in each bitter sip.

The sunset paints the sky in hues we've never
Shared together, yet I feel you there.
Watching colors fade through unseen eyes,
Breathing wonder through unspoken words.

Perhaps there's magic in this longing space,
Where you exist most purely in my mind.

SOLITARY WANDERER

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
A constellation burning in my chest.
Each step becomes a prayer, a meditation,
Your name the mantra humming through my veins.

The world transforms into a secret letter,
Each fallen leaf a word you meant to say.
The wind against my skin becomes your whisper,
The distant thunder, laughter kept at bay.

I carry conversations never spoken,
Replies to questions you have never asked.
The weight of them like stones within my pockets,
Collected treasures from an unmapped past.

How strange to miss what I have never held,
To grieve for lips I've never pressed to mine.
To build cathedrals from the dust of dreaming,
And call the empty space between divine.

Yet still I walk, and still I think of you,
The love that shapes my solitude like clay.

FOOTFALLS OF REMEMBRANCE

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
Through autumn streets where golden leaves cascade.
The crunch beneath my feet becomes the rhythm
Of heartbeats synchronized across the fade.

Remembrance is a curious companion,
More present sometimes than your physical form.
It sharpens edges of the world around me,
Transforming mundane paths to something warm.

I pass the bench where once we sat in silence,
Content to simply breathe the same sweet air.
Now emptiness sits heavy in your absence,
A presence paradoxically aware.

The distance is both tyranny and freedom,
A space where I can hold you perfectly.
Preserved in amber of my recollection,
Unchanging in love's strange eternity.

So as I walk these solitary miles,
I'm never truly walking them alone.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I walk alone, I think of you my love'

responses.text:
When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
Your laughter dancing on the evening breeze.
The way your fingers intertwined with mine,
As gentle as the rustling autumn leaves.

Your absence carves a hollow in my chest,
A void that widens with each solitary stride.
Yet memories bloom like wildflowers in spring,
Across the barren landscape of my mind.

The setting sun reminds me of your smile,
Warm and radiant against approaching night.
And in the stars, I trace the constellation
Of moments we shared beneath their distant light.

So though my shadow walks as one along this path,
In truth, beloved, we are never truly apart.
For in my thoughts you walk these miles with me,
Eternal companion of my wandering heart.

FOOTSTEPS IN SOLITUDE

When I walk alone, I think of you my love
Through city streets where strangers hurry by.
Your phantom presence hovers at my side,
A whispered echo in the urban sigh.

The concrete paths beneath my weary feet
Become the sandy shores we once explored.
Each traffic light, a pause to reminisce
On promises we made but never moored.

The coffee shops we frequented still stand,
Though I no longer enter through their doors.
The memories too bitter and too sweet,
Like sugar mixed with salt upon the shore.

I carry conversations in my head,
Replies to questions you will never ask.
And wonder if in your own solitude,
You think of me, a ghost of seasons past.

PHANTOM COMPANION

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
How strange that absence makes you more complete.
The space beside me filled with ghostly steps,
Your rhythm matching mine along the street.

The city transforms to a gallery
Of moments framed by our shared history—
That bench where first we kissed beneath the rain,
The café window where you smiled at me.

I hear your voice in every passing breeze,
Advising, teasing, whispering my name.
The world becomes a palimpsest of you,
Each landmark bearing traces of your flame.

Perhaps this is love's curious alchemy—
To turn the lead of loneliness to gold.
To walk with phantoms more alive than life,
And find in solitude what hearts can hold.

SOLITARY WANDERER

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
Not with the ache of fresh and bleeding grief,
But as a traveler recalls a distant home—
With quiet longing seeking no relief.

The mountains I traverse speak with your voice,
Their ancient wisdom echoing your own.
The rivers rush with stories you once told,
Of childhood adventures and dreams outgrown.

I gather wildflowers you'll never see,
Name constellations you taught me to find.
The wilderness becomes our meeting place,
Where separation blurs in heart and mind.

Perhaps all wanderers carry ghosts like these,
Companions forged from memory and light.
For when I walk alone beneath vast skies,
Your love transforms my solitude to flight.

URBAN REVERIE

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
Amid the chaos of the subway crowd.
Your face appears in strangers passing by,
A fleeting glimpse that makes my heart beat loud.

The city hums with electronic pulse,
A backdrop to the rhythm of my thoughts.
I check my phone for messages not sent,
For conversations time and distance thwart.

I pass our favorite bookstore, now renamed,
The window display changed to something new.
Yet in my mind, I see us browsing shelves,
Your fingers tracing spines of faded blue.

The world moves forward with relentless pace,
While I exist between what was and is.
A time traveler trapped between two worlds,
Still walking paths where your ghost shadows live.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I walk alone, I think of you my love'

responses.text:
When I walk alone, I think of you my love
In shadows cast by streetlights overhead,
Your memory follows like a gentle dove
Whispering words we've previously said.

The evening air carries your fragrant trace,
A phantom touch upon my restless skin.
I search the stars to find your distant face,
And feel your heartbeat deep within.

My footsteps echo on the empty street,
A rhythm matching what our hearts once shared.
The distance between us—bitter, not sweet—
Yet somehow in this space, you're always there.

When I walk alone, I'm never truly so,
For in my thoughts, with you, I always go.

When I walk alone, I think of you my love
Beneath the canopy of autumn trees
Where leaves like memories slowly drift above
And dance upon the whispering evening breeze.

I think of laughter shared in summer's light
Of hands entwined like vines upon a wall
Of secrets whispered in the dead of night
And promises that echoed through it all.

The path beneath my feet leads ever on
Through shadowed woods and fields of golden grain
Yet in each step I take since you have gone
I find your presence easing all my pain.

For solitude is but a thin disguise
When you remain the light behind my eyes.

When I walk alone, I think of you my love
Across dimensions, time and endless space
The universe expands, stars burst above
Yet nothing dims the memory of your face.

I wander through concrete and urban sprawl
A solitary figure in the crowd
Your absence forms an ever-present wall
Your name—unspoken—echoes still so loud.

The city breathes with mechanical life
Steam rising from the grates like ghostly sighs
Each corner turned reveals our joy and strife
In fragments caught between the earth and skies.

Alone I walk, but never truly so—
In quantum realms, together still we go.

When I walk alone, I think of you my love
Not with the sting of tears or bitter rue
But gentle smiles that lift my heart above
The mundane world to skies of deepest blue.

The pebbles crunch beneath my wandering feet
As waves crash rhythmic on the distant shore
I taste the salt air, tangy-sharp and sweet
Remembering days when we walked here before.

The seagulls call your name upon the wind
The setting sun paints colors you would praise
I gather shells and stones that you would find
Preserving moments from our bygone days.

So though I journey on this path alone
Your spirit walks beside me, flesh and bone.

When I walk alone, I think of you my love
Through crowded streets where strangers brush my sleeve
Yet in this sea of faces, rise above
The lonely thoughts that make my heart aggrieve.

I see you in the window's reflection
A glimpse so brief it might not be at all
Perhaps a trick of light, a misdirection
A phantom hope that answers to my call.

The city hums with life I cannot feel
The traffic lights change green to red to gold
While memories of you, so sharp and real
Defy the passing years, refuse to fold.

So let me walk these paths in solitude
For in my thoughts, with you, I'm never crude.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I walk alone, I think of you my love'

responses.text:
When I walk alone, I think of you my love
Footsteps echoing on empty streets at dusk.
Your memory walks beside me like a ghost,
Fingers intertwined with whispers of the wind.

The city lights blur into constellations,
Each one a moment we once shared together.
I trace your name across the evening sky,
And feel you in the spaces between stars.

Time stretches like shadows across pavement,
Lengthening with each step that takes me home.
A home that feels too quiet without your laugh,
Too hollow without your heartbeat matching mine.

When I walk alone, I'm never truly solo—
You've etched yourself so deeply in my soul
That every path I take, you're there beside me,
A constant compass guiding me back to love.

SOLITARY WANDERINGS

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
Beneath the canopy of autumn's golden tears.
Each fallen leaf a memory we once shared,
Each rustling sound your whisper in my ears.

The cobblestone path winds through shadowed parks
Where once we strolled with fingers interlaced.
Now only phantom pressure warms my palm,
Your absence somehow taking up more space.

The distance between us measured not in miles
But in the countless heartbeats since you've gone.
I collect moments like stones along the shore,
Polished by time, yet heavy as I move on.

Perhaps someday our separate paths will cross,
Like rivers meeting after long descent.
Until that day, I'll walk these roads alone,
With you beside me only in lament.

ECHOES OF ABSENCE

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
As twilight paints the sky in shades of you.
The colors that you loved—soft pink and blue—
Spread wide across the canvas up above.

The gentle breeze that plays among the trees
Reminds me of your laughter, light and free.
The distant call of birds in harmony
Echoes the music of your memories.

I find you in the wildflowers by the path,
Resilient blooms that flourish through the stone.
I see your courage in their silent growth,
Their beauty in harsh places, like your own.

Though miles and circumstance may keep us parted,
My solitary walks are never lonely.
For in the quiet spaces of my heart,
Your love walks faithfully beside me only.

SHADOWS AND LIGHT

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
The shadow stretching long behind my frame
Is shaped like your silhouette, just the same
As when we walked beneath the stars above.

The city hums a melody we knew,
A song that only lovers comprehend.
The traffic lights change colors without end—
Red for the heart that bleeds still just for you.

I pass the café where we used to meet,
Your ghost sits waiting at our table still.
I almost wave before the truth reveals
The cruel illusion time cannot conceal.

Yet in this solitude I've come to find
A strange communion with what's left behind.
For in these walks where memories unwind,
I learn to love the spaces undefined.

FOOTFALLS OF REMEMBRANCE

When I walk alone, I think of you my love,
Each footfall strikes a rhythm on the ground
That matches with the beating in my chest—
A metronome of longing, deep, profound.

The city changes face with passing years;
New buildings rise where once we made our vows.
Yet something ancient pulses through these streets,
A timeless thread that memory allows.

I collect fragments of our story still:
The corner where you first reached for my hand,
The bench where tears fell fast like summer rain,
The bridge where futures carefully were planned.

Perhaps all lovers walk these paths unseen,
Tracing the maps of what was, what could be.
I am but one among the countless souls
Who wander, seeking ghosts of history.

When I walk alone, I'm never truly so—
For you, my love, walk every step with me.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough'

responses.text:
The Bard's Flame

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Pressed close to hear the poet's song,
Their calloused hands and faces tough
Softened where they did not belong.

Among the verses, hearts laid bare,
The plowman's words turned soil to gold.
Simple truths that stripped life bare
In tavern light, their stories told.

These men of earth and honest toil
Found dignity in Burns' refrain.
His words, like seeds in fertile soil,
Bloomed hope where there was only pain.

For what is roughness but a shield
Against the world's unfeeling hand?
In poetry, their souls revealed
The gentle dreams they understand.

ROUGH EDGES

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
With whiskey breath and weathered skin,
Who found in verse what life denied—
A tender place to nestle in.

These men who never spoke of love
Except through curse and calloused palm,
Would hush like children, eyes alight
When Burns' words cast their healing balm.

I wonder at this alchemy
That turns the coarsest soul to silk,
How poetry can slip between
The hardened ribs of those who wilt

Beneath the weight of thankless days.
Perhaps the roughest hearts beat true
When someone names their silent pain
And makes the broken world anew.

KINDLED SOULS

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Their hands like bark, their voices gravel.
Not scholars they, but wisdom-stuffed,
Life's hardships etched in lines of battle.

In tavern's glow they gathered close
To hear the farmer-poet's verse.
The words like whisky warmed their ghosts,
Made bearable what they'd rehearsed.

What miracle that syllables
Could crack the shell of calloused hearts.
The plow-hand's truth, so simple, pulls
Down walls that kept these men apart.

For Burns spoke not of distant things
But daily bread and common love.
The brotherhood his language brings
Makes equals of the push and shove.

Remember this: the roughest hand
May harbor gentlest poetry.

UNEXPECTED TEARS

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Gathered 'round hearths of crackling flame,
Their laughter like the ocean's chuff,
Their hearts untamed, yet not the same.

For when the verses touched their ears—
Of mouse and louse and honest toil—
These hardened souls shed unseen tears
Like morning dew on frozen soil.

What magic lurks in simple rhyme
That breaks the dam of stoic pride?
What alchemy transforms the grime
Of daily strife to joy inside?

Perhaps the roughest men know best
The fragile truth in Burns' refrain:
That beauty's found in nature's breast,
And dignity in honest pain.

So judge not harshly those who wear
Their calluses like battle scars.

THE PLOWMAN'S AUDIENCE

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Wore poetry like second skin.
Though hands were scarred and voices gruff,
Their souls were tender deep within.

The Plowman Poet knew their hearts—
The sting of want, the crush of debt.
He fashioned from life's broken parts
A mirror where their eyes were met.

No flowery verse for scholar's page,
But honest words like daily bread.
They found themselves on every stage
He built from what went unsaid.

The tavern hushes when they speak
His lines, transformed to sacred prayer.
These men, deemed common, coarse and weak,
Become through Burns both whole and rare.

For what is art if not the bridge
Where roughest hands touch gentle truth?

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough'

responses.text:
THE BARD'S ECHO

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Pressed close to hear the poet's verse,
Their calloused hands and faces tough
Softened as words their souls immerse.

These laborers of field and mine,
Stood silent in the tavern's glow,
As verses sweet as heather wine
Revealed the truths they'd come to know.

For in the common tongue he sang
Of love and loss and Scotland's heart,
Each syllable like church bells rang
Elevating life to art.

The plow, the scythe, the daily toil—
Transfigured through his humble pen,
He found the gold within the soil
And dignity in working men.

Though scholars claim the highest art,
'Tis Burns who speaks to roughened hands,
For he knew well the common heart
That beats across these rugged lands.

ROUGH HANDS, GENTLE SOULS

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Gathered 'round hearths of crackling flame,
Their weathered faces, stern and gruff,
Lit up at mention of his name.

These men who rarely bent to tears
Would weep at verses simply told,
Finding in rhyme their hopes and fears,
More precious than the finest gold.

The plowman-poet understood
The dignity in daily bread,
How beauty dwells in solitude
And truth in what remains unsaid.

Beneath the stars on winter nights,
They'd quote his lines with reverent breath,
Finding in words their small delights,
Defiance against toil and death.

For Burns made sacred common things—
A mouse, a louse, a timid flower—
Proving that everyone who sings
Possesses revolutionary power.

UNLIKELY DISCIPLES

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Sat transfixed by poetry's grace,
Their lives defined by work and bluff,
Found in his words their rightful place.

The tavern hushed as verses flowed
From lips unused to gentle speech,
How strange these seeds of beauty showed
In soil where hardship loved to reach.

These men who cursed the breaking dawn
And fought against the dying light,
Found in Burns' words their souls redrawn,
Their hidden tenderness brought right.

What magic lies in honest verse
That breaks the walls of class and pride?
What power can so well disperse
The masks that men so often hide?

Perhaps in Burns they recognized
A mirror to their unheard song,
A voice that never compromised,
A heart both vulnerable and strong.

THE PLOUGHMAN'S BROTHERHOOD

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
With dirt beneath their fingernails,
Whose lives seemed simple, harsh, and tough,
Whose stories rarely filled the tales.

Yet in those eyes of flint and steel
A flicker of recognition burned,
For Burns spoke truths they too could feel—
The wisdom honestly earned.

"A man's a man for a' that," rings
Through taverns, fields, and cobbled streets,
A declaration that upbrings
The soul each working body keeps.

They guard his words like precious coins,
These men dismissed as common clay,
For in his verse, their world rejoins
The beauty stripped by toil away.

The gentleman may scoff and sneer
At hands too rough for delicate arts,
Yet Burns revealed what burns most clear:
The finest poems come from honest hearts.

UNEXPECTED DISCIPLES

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Their shoulders bent from years of toil,
Their language raw, their manner gruff,
Their hands embedded with the soil.

Yet something in the poet's lines
Transformed these weathered, calloused men,
As if the sweetest of wines
Had flowed from some forbidden glen.

They'd quote from memory verses long,
These men who barely learned to write,
And in their voices, rough but strong,
The words of Burns took second flight.

What contradiction here appears—
These rugged souls, these tender hearts,
Who carried through their working years
The solace that true verse imparts.

Perhaps all souls require beauty's touch,
Regardless of their outward shell,
And Burns, who understood as much,
Gave voice to what they could not tell.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough'

responses.text:
Weathered Wisdom

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Pressed against the Highland wind,
Their calloused hands and spirits tough,
Yet gentle hearts beat deep within.

Through whisky haze and peat smoke thick,
Their poetry flowed unrefined,
Not bound by scholar's rhetoric
But born where labor, life entwined.

These men who knew the soil and sweat,
Who cursed the dawn and blessed the night,
Whose laughter rang without regret
As candlelight turned darkness bright.

For in their rudeness, truth shone clear,
Unvarnished wisdom, raw and real.
No polished phrase could come so near
To what the common heart can feel.

He spoke of Burns, but spoke of them—
The unsung bards of field and glen,
Whose roughness was their diadem,
These honest, rude, and roughened men.

Diamonds Unpolished

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
With tongues like thistles, sharp yet true,
Their words, though lacking scholar's fluff,
Carved deeper than the learned few.

Beneath the crust of manner coarse,
Lay souls that felt the world too much,
A tenderness of greater force
Than those who feared the human touch.

They gathered 'round the tavern fire,
These shepherds, farmers, working hands,
Whose untaught hearts could still aspire
To truths no college understands.

The plowman poet showed their worth—
How wisdom grows from common soil,
How beauty needs no noble birth,
But blooms amid the daily toil.

So judge not harshly those whose ways
Seem rough-hewn as the mountain stone.
For often in their simple phrase
Lies truth that kings have never known.

Caledonian Souls

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Whose hands were maps of toil and time,
Their laughter like the heather, tough,
Their sorrows deep as coal in mine.

Not theirs, the drawing room's polite
Exchange of words that mean but air.
They spoke as eagles after flight—
Direct and honest, bold and bare.

The highland winds had taught them well
To strip away pretense and show
The naked heart where passions dwell,
Where joy and grief together flow.

In taverns dim and cottage warm,
They raised their voices, raised their glass,
Defied convention, laughed at form,
And honored beauty in each lass.

Remember then, when judging those
Whose manners seem to lack refined grace,
That often where the thistle grows,
The truest poetry finds its place.

The Plowman's Legacy

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
Whose dialect scorned proper speech,
Whose hands, by labor rendered tough,
Held wisdom schools could never teach.

They gathered not in gilded halls
But 'round the hearth where shadows danced,
And there, between the smoke-stained walls,
Their souls, unfiltered, stood enhanced.

No silver spoons had graced their mouths,
No tutors shaped their untamed minds,
Yet from these men of humble South
Came truths the scholar rarely finds.

For Burns himself had walked their path,
Had felt the sting of winter's breath,
Had known both love's and hunger's wrath—
The constant dance of life and death.

So when we seek to understand
The heart that beats in every breast,
Look not to those with soft-skinned hand,
But those by life and time hard-pressed.

Unvarnished Verse

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough,
Untutored in the ways of art,
Their language coarse, their manner gruff,
Yet poetry lived in each heart.

Not theirs to craft a sonnet sweet
With measured words and practiced grace.
Their verse was born where pastures meet
The honest sweat upon a face.

They sang of love not idealized
But flesh and blood and fierce desire,
Of struggles real, not romanticized,
Of hope that burns like peat-fed fire.

Perhaps we've lost what they possessed—
This raw connection to the soil,
This tongue unfettered, unrepressed,
This beauty born of honest toil.

So let us praise these unschooled bards
Whose roughness was their greatest strength,
Who never played by culture's cards,
Yet reached the soul at greater length.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough'

responses.text:
HIGHLAND ECHOES

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Pressed close to hear the lilting verse,
Their calloused hands and faces tough
Softened as words began to nurse
The wounded hearts that life had scarred.

In taverns dim where smoke hung low,
The plowman's poetry unmarred
By pretense, let their spirits grow.
These men of soil and stone and peat,
Who rarely bowed to gentry's will,
Found in his rhymes a sacred seat
Where common souls could drink their fill.

He spoke of Burns, and in that name
The rough-hewn crowd found gentle flame.

THE BARD'S DISCIPLES

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Circled around the crackling fire,
Their weathered faces etched with life,
Eyes gleaming with untamed desire.

The poet's words—a bridge between
Their silent hearts and voiceless dreams—
Transformed their hardened shells to shells
Where tenderness could flow in streams.

These men who battled wind and rain,
Whose hands were maps of toil and pain,
Found in his verse their truths laid bare,
Their humble lives made rich again.

Beneath the stars they stood as kings,
Their spirits soared on borrowed wings,
As Burns' defiant, hopeful song
Gave voice to those who had none long.

ROUGH DIAMONDS

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Leaned forward, glasses raised mid-air,
Their laughter halted, suddenly
The room grew still with silent prayer.

For in those lines of common speech
They recognized their mirrored souls,
The farmer's son who dared to reach
Beyond the furrow's measured goals.

What magic in those Scottish rhymes
That penetrates the hardest heart!
These laborers, these men of grime,
Transformed by unexpected art.

The plow, the scythe, the working hand—
All hallowed in his verse they stand.
He spoke of Burns, and speaking so,
Made dignity from what is low.

BENEATH THE GRIME

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Sat transfixed in the tavern's glow,
Their shoulders stooped from years of toil,
Their faces lined from seeds they sow.

These men who curse and fight and drink,
Whose hands are cracked from honest work,
Found in his poetry a link
To beauty where their dreams still lurk.

For Burns spoke not of lofty things
But mice and lice and love's sweet sting,
Of poverty and winter's bite,
Of freedom as the soul's birthright.

And in those words, so plainly wrought,
These rough men found what they had sought—
A mirror to their simple lives
Where dignity, like heather, thrives.

THE UNEXPECTED GENTLEMEN

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Shed silent tears they'd never show
In daylight hours or sober rooms
Where vulnerability dare not grow.

These men of mine and field and forge,
Whose language rarely rose to art,
Found in the plowman's honest verse
The tender chambers of the heart.

How strange to see their hardened frames
Grow soft around the edges, warm,
As Burns' rebellious, loving lines
Took shelter from judgment's storm.

These men, dismissed by genteel sorts
As brutes unfit for finer thought,
Revealed the truth that poetry knows—
That souls are never what they ought.

He spoke of Burns, and speaking thus,
Made brothers of the scorned and us.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough'

responses.text:
THE POET'S ECHO

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Pressed close to hear the tender verse,
Their calloused hands and weathered brows
Softened beneath poetic curse.

These men of soil and sweat and toil,
Whose lives were etched in hardened lines,
Found gentle refuge in the words
That flowed like rare, forbidden wines.

What magic dwells in crafted phrase
That breaks the shell of roughened souls?
What alchemy transforms the crude
To vessels where compassion flows?

Perhaps in Burns they saw themselves—
The common man made luminous,
The everyday transfigured bright,
Their struggles rendered glorious.

He spoke of Burns: and in that space
Between the rough and poetry's grace,
Humanity found common ground
Where hardened hearts could be unbound.

ROUGH HANDS, GENTLE HEARTS

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Leaned forward on their battered chairs,
Their whiskey breaths and uncut beards
Belied the tears that gathered there.

The Scottish bard, their working saint,
Whose plowman's hands penned truths so raw
That even in this frontier town
These broken men stood hushed in awe.

What is it in a poet's voice
That penetrates the thickest skin?
That makes the miner pause his pick,
The logger rest his weathered limbs?

Perhaps it's recognition's spark—
The mirror held to common lives,
The dignity in daily bread,
The beauty in how man survives.

So gathered 'round the tavern fire,
These rough-hewn souls, by life made tough,
Found gentleness in verses shared
When he spoke of Burns, and men transformed.

THE UNEXPECTED AUDIENCE

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Fell silent as the verses flowed,
Their usual curses set aside
As tender words among them glowed.

Ironic how the coarsest hands
Could hold a poem with such care,
As if these stanzas might dissolve
If clutched too tightly in the air.

The tavern's smoke hung motionless,
The barkeep paused mid-pouring drinks,
As Rabbie's ghosts walked through the room
And forced these hardened men to think.

Of mice and men and lice and love,
Of nature's grace and time's swift wing—
These laborers with broken nails
Discovered how their souls could sing.

So judge not by the roughened shell
What depths of feeling might reside
In those whom fortune's made uncouth—
The finest hearts oft dwell inside.

BURNS IN THE LUMBER CAMP

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
With axes resting by their sides,
Their flannel shirts still forest-damp,
Their eyes now wide as evening tide.

The scholar thought his words would fall
On stony ground and barren soil,
Yet found instead a hunger there
Among these men of endless toil.

"A man's a man for a' that," quoted
One whose hands were scarred and split.
"To see oursels as others see us,"
Muttered one by window lit.

How strange that Burns, himself once poor,
A farmer fighting failing earth,
Could bridge two centuries and worlds
To validate these men's own worth.

Remind me, then, when judging those
Whose grammar falters, speech is gruff:
The deepest souls wear roughest clothes—
As proven when he spoke of Burns.

THE UNLIKELY CONGREGATION

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Grew still as statues carved from stone.
These miners, farmers, railroad men
Whose hardships matched the poet's own.

No education graced their minds
Beyond what life had harshly taught;
No literary circles claimed
These laborers whose lives were fraught.

Yet something in the Scotsman's verse—
Its democratic heart laid bare—
Spoke to the universal truths
That privileged and poor both share.

A mouse upturned by careless plow,
A louse upon a lady's bonnet,
The honest poverty that stands
Proud despite the wealthy's scorn of it.

So let us not mistake rough hands
For minds that cannot grasp the fine.
The deepest wells of human thought
Need no gilded cup to shine.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough'

responses.text:
ECHOES OF BURNS

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Pressed close to hear the tavern tale,
Of how a plowman's words could sail
Beyond the fields and farm and stall.

Those calloused hands that held the glass,
Those weathered faces etched by time,
Found solace in the rebel's rhyme
That made the high and mighty fall.

For Burns had been one just like them—
A man who toiled beneath the sun,
Whose poetry had somehow spun
Their common cloth to threads of gold.

They nodded as the verses flowed,
These men with backs bent hard by life,
Who knew of struggle, knew of strife,
Yet found themselves in words so bold.

He spoke of Burns: and in that space
The rough were gentle, crude refined,
As poetry unlocked the mind
And showed the soul beneath the face.

THE BARD'S DISCIPLES

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Gathered around like moths to flame,
Their whiskey breath and hands of stone
Softened by mention of that name.

The poet who walked behind the plow,
Whose verses turned the soil of souls,
Whose common touch made kings of them—
The forgotten men with humble goals.

Their laughter, harsh as winter wind,
Gave way to silence, deep and true,
As lines from 'Holy Willie's Prayer'
Revealed what each man always knew:

That underneath their roughened shells,
Behind their oaths and bitter scowls,
Lay hearts that yearned for something pure,
For beauty midst their labored toils.

He spoke of Burns: and in that room
The coarse grew gentle, if but brief—
A brotherhood of broken men
United in their shared belief
That words could lift them from the mud
And make their common struggles known
To lords who'd never felt the sting
Of living by one's sweat alone.

WORKING MEN'S PROPHET

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Leaned forward, elbows on the wood,
Their faces lined like ancient maps
Of battles fought and understood.

The tavern's smoke hung thick as grief
Around their shoulders, bent and wide.
They wore their labor like a coat
With pockets full of stubborn pride.

These were not men of lettered ways,
Nor scholars versed in classic tongue,
Yet Burns had given voice to them,
The unanointed and unsung.

His words—a mirror to their lives—
Reflected back their joy and pain,
The honest toil, the simple truths,
The love of land and falling rain.

A silence fell across the room
As verses crossed the speaker's lips.
These hardened men, with softened eyes,
Found freedom in his fellowship.

For in the bard of Ayrshire's lines,
These rough-hewn souls could clearly see
The dignity in common things—
Their own immortality.

THE PLOWMAN'S VOICE

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Sat transfixed by tales retold,
Of how a farmer's son could craft
Such verses worth their weight in gold.

These men with dirt beneath their nails,
With faces weathered by the years,
Found in the poet's humble words
A validation of their fears.

No flowery speech or lofty thoughts,
No grand philosophies obscure—
Just honest words for honest folk
Whose lives were difficult but pure.

The mice turned from their plowed-up homes,
The daisy crushed beneath the blade,
The working poor, the common folk,
In Burns' vision, all were made

Equal in dignity and worth,
Despite society's cold stare.
These rough men nodded, understood—
The plowman-poet laid them bare.

For in the tavern's amber light,
As tankards emptied, spirits rose,
Burns' legacy lived on in them—
The poetry that no one chose
To silence, though the years rolled by,
And Scotland's son was laid to rest.
His words still burned in hearts like theirs—
The rude, the rough, the dispossessed.

KINDRED SPIRITS

He spoke of Burns: men rude and rough
Grew silent as the name was said.
A reverence fell upon the room
As if they stood beside his bed
Where Scotland's son had drawn his last
And painful breath so long ago.

These men, with hands like gnarled oak,
With faces carved by wind and woe,
Saw in the poet's fiery verse
A mirror to their own desires—
To be acknowledged, to be heard
Beyond the reach of smoky fires
That warmed their bones but not their hearts.

The speaker quoted 'A Man's A Man'
And heads nodded in solemn time,
Acknowledging the simple plan
That worth comes not from wealth or rank
But from the soul that dwells within.

These laborers, these working men,
Whose lives were etched with toil and sin,
Found kinship with the plowman's son
Who dared to speak of love and life,
Of freedom, justice, common good,
Of nature's beauty, human strife.

He spoke of Burns—and in that name
These rough men found themselves redeemed,
Their coarseness turned to quiet strength,
More noble than they'd ever dreamed.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shall I wasting in despair'

responses.text:
Shall I wasting in despair
Die because a woman's fair?
Or make pale my cheeks with care
Cause another's rosy are?
Be she fairer than the day,
Or the flow'ry meads in May,
If she be not so to me,
What care I how fair she be?

Shall my heart be torn asunder
By the weight of worldly thunder?
Shall I let my spirit sink
At the brink of what they think?
Be the world cruel or kind,
Or my fortune gold or lined
With the rags of poverty,
What care I how rich life be?

Shall I wasting in despair
Chase shadows through the midnight air?
When stars collapse and dreams decay,
And hope seems but a distant ray.

The hollow echo of my heart
Reverberates in rooms apart
From joy and laughter, love and light—
A solitary, endless night.

Yet in this darkness, seeds may grow
Of strength I never thought to know.
Perhaps despair is but the soil
Where courage blooms through pain and toil.

So let me waste not in the gloom
But find within this living tomb
A door that opens to the sky
Where I, transformed, at last may fly.

Shall I wasting in despair
Build castles out of morning air?
While time slips through my trembling hands
Like ancient, unforgiving sands.

The mirror shows a stranger's face
Worn thin by sorrow's slow embrace.
Each breath a labor, each day long—
A broken verse in life's short song.

But listen: hear the sparrow sing
Defiant notes on fragile wing?
See how the willow, bent with rain,
Still rises, green with life again?

Perhaps despair is not the end
But just a corner we must bend.
The darkest hour before the light
That guides us through the longest night.

Shall I wasting in despair
Forget the beauty everywhere?
The sunset's glow, the ocean's roar,
The simple joys I once adored?

Despair, a thief of precious time,
Steals moments that could be sublime.
It wraps around my thoughts like vine,
Obscuring stars that ought to shine.

I choose instead to light a flame
Against the darkness and the shame.
To find in every broken piece
A chance for wonder to increase.

For what is life but brief display
Of courage in the light of day?
So I shall waste no more in grief
But plant in sorrow, joy's relief.

Shall I wasting in despair
Become the ghost I sensed was there?
The hollow shell of former might,
A shadow fading into night?

The world keeps spinning, heedless, cold,
As stories end and new unfold.
My pain—a droplet in the sea
Of cosmic insignificancy.

Yet in this vastness, strange to tell,
A single spark may light the well
Of darkness where we often dwell
And break despair's enchanting spell.

So let me turn from inward gaze
To find within this tangled maze
The thread that leads through darkest days
To dawn that sets the world ablaze.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shall I wasting in despair'

responses.text:
Shall I wasting in despair
Die because a woman's fair?
Or make pale my cheeks with care
Because another's rosy are?

No, the stars that guide my path
Shine regardless of love's wrath.
I shall rise above this pain,
Let my spirit breathe again.

Why should sorrow claim my days
When the world has countless ways
To fill a heart with joy anew?
There are mountains left to view.

Shall I wasting in despair
Surrender to the cold night air?
No, I'll kindle flames within
And let a braver life begin.

Shall I wasting in despair
Cling to shadows lingering there?
While the clock ticks hours away
And sunlight fades to ashen gray?

I have counted every tear
That fell upon these pages here.
Each drop a testament to grief
That offers neither calm nor relief.

The hollow echo of your name
Resounds through chambers of my shame.
Yet somewhere in this labyrinth dark,
A distant hope retains its spark.

Perhaps in wasting, I shall find
The strength to leave these chains behind.
For in the depths of my despair,
Some truth awaits discovery there.

Shall I wasting in despair
Become the ghost I most fear?
A wisp of who I used to be,
A shadow of identity?

The mirror shows a stranger's face,
Eyes vacant, missing former grace.
Where once stood mountains, now lie plains
Eroded by persistent rains.

But listen—hear that distant drum?
It calls to parts not yet numb.
Reminding of a strength inside
That sorrow hasn't yet denied.

So no, I'll not waste in despair.
Instead, I'll breathe the cleansing air
Of possibility and chance,
And join again life's vibrant dance.

Shall I wasting in despair
Be consumed by thorns of care?
While celestial bodies dance above,
Unmoved by human grief or love?

The universe in vastness spins,
Indifferent to our mortal sins.
Yet here I dwell in sorrow's cave,
A willing prisoner, sorrow's slave.

How strange that I should choose this cell
When freedom's bells continue knell.
How odd that I should close my eyes
To stars that glitter through night skies.

Perhaps in wasting lies a truth:
That we must lose to find our proof
Of what remains when all is stripped—
A soul that cannot be eclipsed.

Shall I wasting in despair
Forget how morning light turns fair
The simplest blade of common grass,
Transforming it to gold and brass?

The mockingbird still finds its song
Though winter nights grow cold and long.
The dormant seed beneath the snow
Prepares in silence still to grow.

Why then should I surrender now
To grief that time will disallow?
For nature teaches patience clear—
All seasons change throughout the year.

So I shall rise from this dark place
And meet tomorrow face to face.
Not wasting in despair's embrace,
But moving forward, finding grace.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shall I wasting in despair'

responses.text:
Shall I wasting in despair
Die because a woman's fair?
Or make pale my cheeks with care
Cause another's rosy are?
Be she fairer than the day,
Or the flow'ry meads in May,
If she be not so to me,
What care I how fair she be?

Shall my heart be torn apart
By a glance, a voice, a start?
Shall I give my soul away
For a hope that cannot stay?
Time flows like a river deep,
And what we sow, we shall reap.
If my love brings only pain,
Better to stand tall again.

Shall I wasting in despair
Linger in the shadows' lair?
While the moon above me glows
And the night wind gently blows?

Shall I count each passing star
Wondering where your footsteps are?
Shall I measure every breath
In this living kind of death?

No—I'll rise from ashes cold
Forge myself in stories told
By the ancients who once knew
That despair is just a view.

I will plant my feet on ground
Where my strength is newly found
And though tears may sometimes fall
I shall stand both proud and tall.

Shall I wasting in despair
Drown beneath the weight of air?
Shall I let my spirit sink
At the precipice's brink?

The abyss calls out my name
Whispering songs of guilt and shame
Yet within this darkened place
Flickers still a light of grace.

Desperation holds no truth
Beyond the sorrows of our youth
For in each ending starts anew
A path that carries us all through.

So I'll gather broken parts
Of these fragile human hearts
And from fragments, jagged, torn
Something beautiful is born.

Shall I wasting in despair
Clutch at memories stripped bare?
Hollow echoes of the past
Shadows that refuse to last.

The clock ticks on relentlessly
As time consumes identity
Yet somewhere in this vast unknown
A seed of hope remains unsown.

Perhaps within the darkest night
When stars withdraw their distant light
The universe conspires to show
That from our pain, we truly grow.

So let me face what lies ahead
Not bound by tears I've yet to shed
For in despair's encompassing arms
I've found my strength, my truth, my charms.

Shall I wasting in despair
Become what I cannot bear?
A hollow vessel, emptied out
Filled with nothing but my doubt?

The ravens circle overhead
Feeding on the words unsaid
While I, a statue carved from grief
Stand motionless without relief.

Yet water shapes the hardest stone
And no one truly stands alone
For even in the darkest hour
Life contains transforming power.

So from this wasteland I shall rise
With newfound wisdom in my eyes
And though despair once knew my name
I am no longer quite the same.

responses.text:

Surrender to the darkened air?
Let shadows claim my beating heart

No—I shall rise against the tide

Shall I wasting in despair
Watch as moments slip away?
Like sand through fingers, thin as air,
The clock of life marks each day.

This hollow ache within my chest,
A void where hope once bloomed bright,
Now houses ghosts that never rest,
Who haunt me through the endless night.

Yet in this darkness I perceive
A distant glimmer, faint but true.
Perhaps in time I might believe
That light can fill this darkness too.

Shall I wasting in despair?
No—I choose to rise and dare.

Shall I wasting in despair
Linger in the shadows' hold?
While autumn whispers through my hair
And summer's tales grow old.

The mirror shows a stranger's face
With eyes that no longer shine,
A soul adrift in empty space
Where stars refuse to align.

But listen—hear the morning bird
Sing sweetly through the rain.
Its melody, though often blurred,
Reminds: nothing stays the same.

So gather now your broken parts,
Embrace the pain that teaches most.
For stronger grow the mended hearts
That weathered despair's bitter host.

Shall I wasting in despair
Become a vessel for the night?
A hollow shell beyond repair,
A candle robbed of light?

The world spins on despite my grief,
The stars care not for human pain.
The universe grants no relief
To those who call its name in vain.

Yet in this cosmic indifference
I find a strange and wild release.
If nothing matters in this sense,
Then I am free to seek my peace.

From ashes of despair I'll craft
A phoenix soul that laughs and soars,
And drink of life's mysterious draft
That flows through all eternal doors.

Shall I wasting in despair
Forget the taste of morning dew?
Or how the sunset paints the air
In shades of gold and crimson hue?

The river of my tears has carved
A canyon through my weary heart.
Of joy and hope I've been so starved
That I forgot where healing starts.

But despair is not my master,
Though it claims to know my name.
I'll rise above disaster,
Light my soul with inner flame.

For even in the darkest night,
When stars hide from my seeking eyes,
I carry still that sacred light
That neither fades nor dies.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shall I wasting in despair'

responses.text:
Shall I wasting in despair
Die because a woman's fair?
Or make pale my cheeks with care
Cause another's rosy are?
Be she fairer than the day,
Or the flowery meads in May,
If she be not so to me,
What care I how fair she be?

Shall my heart be torn asunder
By the weight of mortal wonder?
Shall I chase the fading light
Through the cold and endless night?
Let the stars burn out above,
Let the oceans cease to move,
If I cannot find my peace,
What care I if time should cease?

Shall I wasting in despair
Trace my sorrows through the air?
Shall I count each fallen tear
As the empty hours appear?

No, I'll rise from ashes gray
Find my strength in breaking day
Turn my face toward the sun
Let despair's dark threads unspun

For what profit comes from grief
Endless pain without relief?
I shall forge from bitter flame
Something new that bears no name

Shall I wasting in despair?
No—I choose the light to bear
From the depths I now ascend
Begin again, break, and mend.

Shall I wasting in despair
Surrender to the void's cold stare?
Shall I let my spirit drain
Into cups of endless pain?

The clock ticks on indifferent walls
As shadow after shadow falls
Across the chamber of my mind
Where hope and fear are intertwined

Perhaps despair itself contains
The seeds of wisdom in its pains
Perhaps in darkness we might see
The stars that guide us to be free

So shall I wasting in despair?
I'll waste no more in waiting there
For dawn arrives on broken wings
And even grief, in time, still sings.

Shall I wasting in despair
Build castles out of empty air?
Shall I count the grains of sand
Slipping through my outstretched hand?

The ocean roars its ancient song
Of things that never last for long
The mountains whisper to the trees
Of time's relentless mysteries

Why should I surrender now
To sorrow's weight upon my brow?
Why should I believe the lie
That hope must wither, dreams must die?

No, I shall not waste away
In despair's unending gray
I'll gather fragments of the light
And piece together what is bright.

Shall I wasting in despair
Be consumed by thorns of care?
Shall I drown in bitter seas
While chained to haunting memories?

The raven calls across the moor
Its voice the same as times before
When I stood tall against the gale
Before my courage seemed to fail

Despair, that thief of precious time
That steals the rhythm from the rhyme
That paints the world in shades of gray
And hides the promise of new day

I choose to cast this shroud aside
No more in shadows shall I hide
For even in the darkest hour
Hope remains the sweetest flower.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shall I wasting in despair'

responses.text:
Shall I wasting in despair
Die because a woman's fair?
Or make pale my cheeks with care
Because another's rosy are?
Be she fairer than the day,
Or the flowery meads in May,
If she be not so to me,
What care I how fair she be?

Shall my heart be torn asunder
By the chains I've placed it under?
Shall I count the hours away
When sunshine turns to dismal gray?
No, I'll rise above this pain,
Let my spirit break this chain.
Though the night seems dark and long,
Dawn arrives with hopeful song.

Shall I wasting in despair
Drown beneath the weight of air?
Moments slip like grains of sand
Through the hollow of my hand.

Mountains crumble, oceans dry,
Stars extinguish in the sky,
Yet my sorrow lingers still,
Eternal as an ancient hill.

But wait—what light breaks through the cloud?
A whisper soft, yet speaking loud.
Perhaps despair is but a choice,
A shadow given needless voice.

I rise, though trembling, to my feet,
Refusing final, dark defeat.
For even in the deepest night,
One candle holds tremendous light.

Shall I wasting in despair
Forget the beauty everywhere?
The morning dew on spider's thread,
The sunset painting mountains red?

Shall I let my spirit sink
Beneath dark waters where I drink
From cups of sorrow, bitter sweet,
While life continues, incomplete?

No, I shall lift my weary eyes
To catch the wonder of sunrise.
I'll gather fragments of my heart
And piece together works of art.

Despair may knock upon my door,
But hope resides forevermore
In chambers deep within my breast
Where even pain may come to rest.

Shall I wasting in despair
Become a ghost who's barely there?
A shadow of what once was whole,
A fading echo of a soul?

The clock ticks on with ruthless beat,
While I remain in my defeat,
A statue carved from silent stone,
In barren gardens, all alone.

Yet something stirs within the dust,
A spark that will not yield to rust.
Perhaps in this abandoned place,
I'll find a strange, unlooked-for grace.

For from the ashes of what's lost,
New life emerges, tempest-tossed.
And I, though broken, shall arise,
With wisdom burning in my eyes.

Shall I wasting in despair
Cling to memories laid bare?
Shall I count each passing day
As treasure lost along the way?

The mirror shows a stranger's face,
A person lost in time and space.
The world spins on without a care
For one soul wasting in despair.

But hark! A distant melody
Calls forth what I had failed to see:
That darkness serves to show the light,
That day must follow every night.

So from this valley I shall climb,
Embracing pain as paradigm.
For only those who've known the deep
Can truly value mountain steep.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My heart's delight, my soul's most precious treasure.
Time steals you from my arms, a cruel destroyer,
Leaving behind an ache beyond all measure.

I watched you grow from seed to tender sapling,
Your branches reaching toward the endless sky.
Your laughter was the music of my mornings,
Your smile the light that taught my soul to fly.

Now distance claims you for its own possession,
The world awaits with open arms and call.
I stand here, rooted in my love's confession,
Proud witness to your rise, though grieved your fall.

Go forth, beloved child, with my blessing,
Though every step you take breaks me anew.
Remember in your journey's far progressing,
My love remains your compass, strong and true.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
A bittersweet departure marks this day.
Like autumn leaves that from their branches fly,
You too must journey on your separate way.

The cradle that once held your infant form
Now empty stands, a monument to time.
Through sunshine bright and through the raging storm,
I've watched you grow with wonder, child of mine.

The universe has whispered in your ear
Of distant lands where you must stake your claim.
Though tears now fall and cloud my vision clear,
I would not clip your wings nor bring you shame.

So go, dear heart, with courage as your shield,
With wisdom as your staff upon the road.
The lessons of our years together sealed
Within your soul, lightening your heavy load.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
So swift the seasons of our lives have passed.
Like morning dew upon the spider's toy,
These precious moments were not meant to last.

I held you once, so small within my palm,
A miracle of flesh and blood and bone.
Your presence was my spirit's healing balm,
In you, the best of me was clearly shown.

The world now calls you to its vast embrace,
To fields untilled and mountains yet unclimbed.
I stand here frozen in this sacred space,
Where love and loss are perfectly entwined.

Remember as you walk your chosen path,
That distance cannot sever what we share.
For love transcends all boundaries of wrath,
And finds its way through earth and sea and air.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My flesh and blood now rendered unto time.
The universe reclaims what I've enjoyed—
Your presence—like the ending of a rhyme.

I carved your name upon my beating heart,
A talisman against the coming night.
Now destiny compels us both to part,
As darkness must surrender to the light.

What cosmic debt do I now pay in full,
To lose the one who gave my life its meaning?
The silent stars look down, so beautiful, so cruel,
While I am left here, broken, keening.

Yet in this grief, a truth reveals its face:
Love freely given asks no safe return.
So go, beloved, claim your rightful place,
While here, your memory's candle bright will burn.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My anchor in the tempest of this world.
Life's tapestry, with threads of gold and pain deployed,
Now sees your chapter from my own unfurled.

I dream of you amid the distant stars,
Forging your path through heavens yet unknown.
While I remain behind these earthly bars,
Collecting memories of how you've grown.

The echo of your footsteps haunts these halls,
Your shadow dances still upon the wall.
I strain to hear your voice, your distant calls,
As silence answers, heavy as a pall.

But parting is the natural way of things—
The fledgling leaves the nest on untried wings.
So fly, my child, to where your spirit sings,
While in my heart your presence ever clings.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My heart's own treasure, now returned to dust.
The cradle empty where you once did lie,
Your laughter silenced by time's cruel thrust.

I held you once with fingers trembling weak,
A father's pride reflected in your eyes.
Now memory alone is what I seek,
As heaven claims its angel from the skies.

The world grows dimmer in your absence now,
The colors fade, the music loses tone.
Yet in the whispers of the wind somehow,
I feel you near, I am not all alone.

Though grief may bend me like a willow tree,
The love between us lives eternally.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
How swift the seasons of our love have passed.
Like petals scattered by an April wind,
Your presence fades—too beautiful to last.

The universe conspired to bring you forth,
A constellation burning in my sky.
Now cosmic tides pull you beyond my reach,
Leaving salt tracks where tears refuse to dry.

I wonder if the stars feel such regret
When supernovas claim their brightest sons?
Do galaxies mourn as we mortals do
When distance claims what gravity once won?

Perhaps in some dimension yet unknown,
Our souls will recognize what we have grown.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
No longer shall I guide your tender steps.
The garden where we planted dreams together
Must now be tended by your hands alone.

I send you forth like arrows from my bow,
Directed true but flying far from sight.
The target of your life's ambition waits
Beyond horizons I shall never know.

Remember as you journey through the world,
The lessons whispered in your listening ear.
Not chains to bind you to my aging heart,
But wings to lift you when the path grows steep.

Though separation carves its hollow space,
My pride in you shall fill that empty place.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
The clockwork of our days has wound down now.
Where once your footsteps echoed through these halls,
A haunting silence settles, deep and low.

Death came not as a thief but as a friend,
To guide you gently to that distant shore.
While I remain among the breathing ghosts,
Half-living in the space you occupy no more.

The universe contracts around your absence,
A black hole where your laughter used to be.
I orbit this new gravity of grief,
A satellite to loss's cold geometry.

Yet somewhere in this mathematical void,
Our love persists—a constant, unalloyed.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Not flesh of flesh, but heart of beating heart.
Adoption bound us tighter than mere blood—
A choice renewed each dawn, a sacred art.

I did not feel your first kicks from within,
Nor hear your heartbeat merged with my own pulse.
Yet when they placed you in these waiting arms,
The universe revealed its deepest truths.

Now as you leave to craft your separate life,
I marvel at the stranger you've become.
So wonderfully yourself, so wholly new,
A person I could never have designed.

In letting go, I find my greatest pride:
The love that gives you freedom, not just ties.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My heart's reflection in your innocent eyes.
Time has swept you from my trembling grasp,
Like autumn leaves caught in winter's sigh.

I cradled you once, small and new,
A miracle formed of love and light.
Now distance grows between our souls,
As you journey toward your rightful height.

The echo of your laughter haunts these walls,
Where once your footsteps danced with glee.
This hollow house bears witness to your absence,
A monument to what can no longer be.

Yet in this parting, painful though it seems,
I find strange peace in setting you free.
For you were never truly mine to keep,
Only to guide, then watch you flee.

SEVERANCE

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Unmoored now from the harbor of my care.
The cord that bound us, sacred and complete,
Snapped by the cruel scissors of despair.

I search the horizon where you disappeared,
A silhouette against the setting sun.
Your absence carves new hollows in my chest
Where once your steady heartbeat echoed mine.

The universe conspires in cosmic jest—
To grant such love, then snatch it from my hold.
What deity demands such sacrifice?
What lesson hides in grief so sharp and cold?

Perhaps in letting go, I truly love.
Perhaps in loss, I finally understand.
That you were always meant for distant shores,
Beyond the reaching of my mortal hand.

THE INHERITANCE

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Bearer of legacy, keeper of flame.
The world awaits your footprints in its soil,
While I remain, whispering your name.

I've taught you all the lessons I could give—
Of courage, truth, and standing tall through pain.
Now watch as you transform my humble words
Into a symphony of your own refrain.

The bittersweet of parting fills my mouth
With honey-gall of pride and sorrow mixed.
For in your leaving lies my triumph too,
A testament that time cannot transfix.

So go, beloved, with my blessing full,
Carry the torch I've placed within your soul.
Remember me in quiet evening hours,
As I remember you, perfect and whole.

GHOST LIMB

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Phantom ache where once your warmth resided.
Like amputees who feel their missing parts,
I sense you still, though we've been divided.

The universe expands between our hearts—
A cosmic distance growing with each breath.
I reach for you across this starry void,
A gesture futile as defying death.

Your absence has a texture all its own,
Heavy as lead yet weightless as the air.
A paradox of presence in your lack,
A fullness in the emptiness you share.

Perhaps all love must culminate in loss,
The final verse of every human song.
Yet still I sing your name into the night,
And in that music, you are never gone.

BENEDICTION

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My brightest star now claimed by distant skies.
I stand upon this threshold of goodbye,
Torn between celebration and demise.

The clock's hands moved too swiftly through our days,
From first breath to this moment of release.
I never knew that love could be so fierce,
Nor parting such a complicated peace.

What strange alchemy transforms my grief to pride,
As I behold your wings unfurled and strong?
What ancient wisdom whispers to my heart
That in this separation, nothing's wrong?

So go with grace into your rightful life,
Carry my love as talisman, not chain.
For in your freedom lies my greatest gift—
A circle unbroken, despite this pain.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
A blossom plucked before its time to bloom,
The whisper of your laughter, now a void
That echoes through the chambers of my room.

I held you once, small fingers wrapped in mine,
Your eyes reflecting worlds I'd never know.
The future stretched before us, seeming fine—
Until the winds of fate began to blow.

What cosmic debt demanded such a price?
What heavens needed one more star to shine?
The universe in cruel sacrifice
Has taken what was never truly mine.

Yet in the hollow spaces of my heart,
Your memory remains, will not depart.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My quill cannot capture grief's full measure.
Time's thief has stolen what I treasured most,
Leaving only shadows of our pleasure.

The garden where we walked now overgrown,
Wild roses bloom where once your feet would tread.
I wander pathways, haunted and alone,
Conversing with your ghost inside my head.

The world spins on, indifferent to loss,
The sun still rises though my night remains.
I search for meaning in this heavy cross,
But find no answer that explains my pains.

Perhaps someday beyond this mortal coil,
We'll meet again where no tears fall to soil.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Not flesh of flesh but spirit joined to mine.
Creation born of midnight oil and toil,
A work I've crafted, polished line by line.

My manuscript, my offspring of the page,
Now ventures forth beyond my sheltered walls.
To face the world's harsh criticism or praise,
To stand or falter as the judgment falls.

I send you forth with trembling hope and fear,
Uncertain of the welcome you shall find.
Yet know that in these words I hold so dear,
I've left the truest portions of my mind.

Go forth, dear child of ink and thought and pain,
May others love you as I have, the same.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
The seasons change, as must all living things.
The sapling that I nurtured from a seed
Must spread its branches, test its growing wings.

I watch you stride toward horizons new,
Your shadow stretching past our threshold stone.
The lessons taught, the wisdom shared with you,
Now guide your steps as you walk on alone.

Remember as you journey far from here,
The roots that hold you when the tempests rage.
The love that follows, constant, year by year,
Transcending distance, unbound by age.

Though parting brings this bittersweet refrain,
In letting go, I watch you truly gain.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Not gone to dust, but transformed into light.
The universe reclaims its borrowed stars,
Your atoms dance across the endless night.

Science tells us energy never dies,
But shifts and changes, finds a different form.
Yet cold equations offer no replies
To hearts left shattered by grief's sudden storm.

I seek you in the patterns of the rain,
In quantum fields where possibilities bloom.
Perhaps dimensions we cannot explain
Hold space where you still laugh and fill a room.

Until we meet in some cosmic ballet,
I'll carry you within my DNA.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
