Yet in my dreams, I feel your hand in mine,
And in the stars, I glimpse your shining face.
Farewell, my child, though parting brings such pain,
In every heartbeat, you still hold your place.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
A blossom plucked before the fullest bloom.
The universe reclaims what it once gave,
Returning stardust to the cosmic womb.

I watch you drift beyond the veil of sight,
Your essence merging with the endless sky.
No longer bound by flesh and mortal chains,
Yet still I search for you with weeping eye.

What strange geometry of fate decrees
That parents should outlive their precious young?
The natural order twisted out of shape,
Leaving bitter words upon my tongue.

Yet rage subsides like waves upon the shore,
And in its place, a quiet knowing grows.
That love transcends the boundaries of time,
And in my blood, your legacy still flows.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My quill can scarcely capture grief so deep.
The chambers of my heart grow cold and dark,
As shadows lengthen where your light would leap.

I crafted dreams and wove them into plans,
Imagining the paths that you might take.
Now futures unrealized hang suspended,
Like morning mist above a frozen lake.

The world moves forward with relentless pace,
Indifferent to the treasures it has claimed.
While I remain, a monument to loss,
By sorrow's heavy architecture framed.

Yet in this darkness something still remains—
A constellation of remembered days.
Farewell, sweet child, though distance parts our ways,
Your spirit guides me through this tangled maze.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
No longer tethered to this mortal coil.
You've slipped between the fingers of my days,
Like water seeping through the garden soil.

I wonder if you wander distant realms,
Or if your essence simply ceased to be.
Philosophers debate what lies beyond,
But grief needs no complex theology.

The simple truth of absence speaks enough—
The empty chair, the silence in the hall.
The birthday gifts I'll never need to buy,
The name I'll never again need to call.

Yet sometimes when the evening light turns gold,

Farewell, my child, though parted we may be,

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
Not flesh of flesh, but heart of beating heart.
Adoption's bonds, though forged in choice not blood,

I watched you grow beneath another sky,

Two families' stories woven through your soul,
As questions of identity perplex.

The system claims it knows what serves you best,
Cold regulations blind to love's true face.
As courts and papers steal what can't be owned—
The sacred trust that time cannot erase.

Yet know this truth through all your wandering years:
My child you were, my child you shall remain.
Farewell for now, though distance marks our days,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;'

responses.text:
Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My heart's own treasure, now departed hence.
Like autumn leaves that flutter, then destroy
The summer's memory with their absence.

I held you once, so small within my palm,
Your fingers curled around my weathered thumb.
Your laughter was my spirit's soothing balm,
Now silence where your voice once would become.

The years too swift have borne you from my side,
To distant shores where I cannot follow.
Across that vast, immeasurable tide,
Leaving me here in grief's dark hollow.

Yet in the whispers of the evening breeze,
I feel your presence like a gentle ghost.
Among the rustling of the willow trees,

Farewell, sweet joy, though parting breaks my heart,

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
A star extinguished in the morning light.
Time's cruel tide has swept you far from me,
Leaving only shadows where you shone so bright.

I carved your name in bark of ancient trees,
Hoping nature's memory outlasts my own.
Your laughter echoes through forgotten dreams,
A phantom music from a life outgrown.

The world turns cold without your gentle touch,
As winter claims what autumn left behind.
I search for traces of your soul in such
Small moments—fleeting, fragile, undefined.

In empty rooms your absence has more weight
Than mountains pressing down upon my chest.
I stand at crossroads, forced to navigate
A future path without my treasured guest.

So go, dear child, toward horizons new,
Though every step you take breaks me anew.

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My flesh and blood, now scattered to the wind.
No parent should outlive their own creation—
This cosmic order cruelly rescinded.

I planted seeds that blossomed into you,
Watered with love and sunlit with my pride.
How strange that branches outlast mighty trunks,
Yet here I stand while you no longer bide.

The universe contracts around your absence,
Collapsing inward like a dying star.
I grasp at memories—your first steps, first words—
Now precious artifacts of who you are.

Did God require another angel's voice?
Or was this simply fate's indifferent hand?
I rage against the theft of future days,

Though tears may water flowers on your grave,

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;
My apprentice in life's mysterious trade.
I taught you how to navigate the stars,

Remember when we tracked the fox's print?
Or how we named constellations anew?
Your questions opened worlds I'd long forgotten,

Now you depart to craft your own legend,
Armed with lessons earned through shared delight.
The tools I've given may seem insufficient

But trust the compass hidden in your heart,
The wisdom woven through your very bones.
Though separate paths we walk from this day forth,

So sail beyond the edges of my map,

Farewell, thou child of my right hand, and joy;

Adoption forged what nature never could—
A bond transcending arbitrary fate.
I held you first with trembling, hopeful arms,
Not knowing how completely love would take.

And now you leave to find your history,
To trace the roots from which you first emerged.
I release you with both pride and terror,

Through all the doubts that plagued your growing years,
The questions of belonging, place and worth.
Remember as you search for what was lost,

Farewell, dear child not born but fully mine,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'In my first sleep'

responses.text:
In my first sleep
I drift through velvet darkness,
Untethered from day's demands.
Memories dissolve like sugar in rain,
Replaced by landscapes of impossible geometry.

In my first sleep
Time loses its tyranny,
Minutes stretch like taffy,
Hours compress to heartbeats.
I am ageless here.

In my first sleep
Voices call from forgotten corners,
Faces I've never seen yet somehow know
Beckon me deeper into the labyrinth
Where logic surrenders to wonder.

In my first sleep
I am both captain and vessel,
Navigating oceans of subconscious,
Charting stars that exist only in this realm
Where I am most honestly myself.

In my first sleep
I remember what waking forgets—
That I am infinite,
That boundaries are illusions,
That I have always been free.

In my first sleep
I found a garden of silver light
Where moonflowers bloomed in whispers
And time moved like honey from the comb.

The stars hung lower there,
Close enough to catch in cupped hands,
Their ancient light warming my palms
Like embers from a cosmic hearth.

I walked paths of crushed amethyst,
Footprints dissolving behind me
As if I had never been,
Yet somehow always was.

Shadows danced with purpose,
Telling stories without words,
Histories of lives I might have lived
In worlds adjacent to my own.

In my first sleep
I recognized my soul's true face,
Unburdened by daylight's expectations,
Free from the weight of being seen.

And when dawn pulled me back,
I carried fragments like precious stones,
Hidden in pockets of memory
To sustain me through waking hours.

IN MY FIRST SLEEP

In my first sleep, consciousness unravels
like a sweater caught on a nail.
The world's sharp edges soften,
and I become liquid, flowing
through the cracks of reality.

In my first sleep, ancestors gather
at the foot of my bed, their voices
a murmuration of starlings,
rising and falling in patterns
I almost understand.

In my first sleep, mountains form
from the rumpled landscape of sheets,
valleys deepen with each exhale,
rivers of thought carve new channels
through the terrain of possibility.

In my first sleep, I speak languages
never learned, solve equations
never studied, embrace lovers
never met, and grieve losses
never experienced.

In my first sleep, I am ageless,
boundless, formless, infinite—
until the alarm's harsh declaration
reassembles me, atom by atom,
into someone who must remember how to be human.

In my first sleep
I shed the skin of daylight hours
like a snake abandoning
what no longer serves.

The world contracts to the size
of a heartbeat, then expands
beyond the reach of telescopes.

I am both ancient and unborn,
navigating the space between
heartbeats where eternity nests.

In my first sleep
I hear the music of dust motes,
the symphony of cells dividing,
the quiet conversation between
blood and bone.

Memories not my own
visit like curious neighbors,
borrowing sugar, leaving
traces of unfamiliar sweetness.

In my first sleep
I am closest to truth,
when the conscious mind
relinquishes its tyrannical grip
and allows mystery its rightful throne.

It is here, in this threshold space,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'In my first sleep'

responses.text:

I heard the ocean breathing with my lungs,

The desert winds were whistling through my teeth,

As galaxies were spinning in my chest.
In my first sleep, I was no longer mine—

In my first sleep, the veil between worlds thins
As consciousness releases its tight grip.
The theater of dreams slowly begins,

The clock's hands freeze, suspended in the dark,

My body heavy, anchored to the bed,

In my first sleep, I cross the borderline

In my first sleep, I shed the day like skin,

The noise of life grows distant, paper-thin,

The faces I have worn begin to blur,

The boundaries of self begin to stir,

I sink beneath familiar gravity,

In my first sleep, the universe contracts

The pillow holds my head like cupped hands might,

The worries that had anchored me by day

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'In my first sleep'

responses.text:

In my first sleep, I found you again,

In my first sleep, I touched eternity,
felt its vastness spread through my veins,

in the small death of nightly surrender,
where beginnings and endings lose meaning.

In my first sleep, darkness cradles me
like an ancient mother, rocking gently
between worlds of flesh and shadow.
I sink beneath conscious thought,
into waters where time moves differently,
rippling outward from each heartbeat.

The veil between what is and what could be
thins to gossamer, easily torn
by the curious fingers of my dreaming self.
I am both traveler and landscape here,
building castles from the sand of memory,
watching them dissolve in the tide of night.

In my first sleep, I am closest to truth—
not the rigid facts of daylight hours,
but the fluid wisdom of ancestral knowing.
Here, I remember what I never learned,
speak in tongues I've never studied,
and dance with ghosts who smile like family.

In my first sleep, the world unravels
like a sweater caught on a nail—
thread by thread, the day's tight weave
loosens into something formless.

I drift on currents electric and strange,
my body a boat without anchor or sail,
carried by tides of neural firing
into territories unmapped and wild.

The clock on the nightstand loses meaning;
its mechanical heart beats in another dimension
where seconds stretch into centuries
and minutes collapse into milliseconds.

In my first sleep, I am borderless,
a being of pure sensation and thought,
untethered from the physics of waking.
I expand beyond skin and bone,
become atmosphere, become cosmos,
until the first light of dawn
pulls me back into the singular.

In my first sleep, I meet myself
as a child, eyes wide with questions
I've long forgotten how to ask.
We sit by a river that never existed,
throw stones that make no ripples,
and speak of things that matter only here.

The moon hangs differently in this sky,
castling shadows that move against the light,
dancing to music only dreamers hear.
I want to warn my younger self
about the storms that wait ahead,
but find my mouth filled with butterflies instead.

Time folds like origami in this place,
creasing along lines of significant moments—
first kiss, last goodbye, the birth of regret.
In my first sleep, I am archaeologist
of my own buried truths, digging
through layers of pretense and protection,
unearthing artifacts of authentic feeling.

In my first sleep, the mathematics of reality
shift from Euclidean certainty
to the wild geometry of possibility.
Gravity becomes suggestion rather than law;
I float between ceiling and memory,
anchored only by the thin thread of breath.

Colors not found in any waking spectrum
paint landscapes of impossible beauty—
cityscapes built from crystallized emotion,
forests grown from seeds of forgotten conversations.
I navigate by instinct here, where maps are useless
and compasses spin in delirious circles.

In my first sleep, I speak with the dead
who aren't really dead in this realm,
just residing in a different frequency of being.
They offer wisdom wrapped in riddles,
comfort disguised as confusion,
and I wake with salt-tracks on my pillow,
holding fragments that dissolve in daylight.

The night wrapped around me like mother's arms,

In my first sleep, I knew without doubt

Before words carved channels for thoughts to flow,

Now I chase that sleep through restless nights,

In my first sleep, galaxies were born

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,'

responses.text:
IRON ARROW

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
Cutting night's canvas with mechanical precision.
Steel wheels on steel rails, a modern heartbeat starting,
Carrying dreams and strangers toward collision.

Windows illuminate the countryside in flashes,
Brief glimpses of lives we'll never truly know.
The arrow flies on as the landscape dashes
Past sleepy towns where time moves slow.

Inside this vessel, stories intertwine—
Travelers bound by temporary fate.
While outside, stars and moonlight shine
On empty platforms where others wait.

We are all arrows shot through darkness,
Uncertain of the target, yet moving still.
The journey itself our only witness
As we pierce the night with stubborn will.

MIDNIGHT TRANSIT

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
A steel-tipped phantom through the midnight veil.
The passengers within, their journeys starting,
Leave trails of memory along the rail.

It cleaves the sleeping earth with thunderous song,
This mechanical serpent with eyes aglow.
Carrying whispers of where we belong,
Secrets only night travelers know.

The rhythm rocks us into half-dreams,
Where stations blur and time dissolves away.
Reality unstitches at the seams
As landscapes transform into shades of gray.

We are all travelers on this arrow's flight,
Temporary companions in transit's embrace.
Surrendered to the journey through the night,
Until dawn breaks upon our final place.

VELOCITY

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
A constellation of windows, human-bright.
The world outside dissolves, departing
Into smears of shadow and light.

I press my face against cold glass,
Watching my reflection overlap
With fragments of landscape that pass—
A visual collage, a moving map.

The arrow's shaft vibrates with lives,
Strangers bound in metal flight.
Each with stories that arrives
At destinations beyond sight.

In this liminal space between here and there,
We exist suspended, neither gone nor arrived.
The darting arrow cuts through night air,
And in this moment, we are purely alive—

Hurtling forward, unstoppable, free,
Piercing darkness with relentless velocity.

NIGHT PASSAGE

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
Piercing velvet shadows with mechanical might.
A steel-wrought comet, its journey charting
Across the sleeping canvas of night.

I count the rhythmic clacking like heartbeats,
Each one measuring distance from what's known.
The passengers around me—incomplete sheets
Of stories I'll never fully own.

Outside, the world blurs into watercolor dreams,
Trees become brushstrokes, houses mere suggestion.
Reality dissolves at the seams
As speed transforms perception.

We are all arrows shot from unseen bows,
Trajectories determined yet unknown.
Each carriage filled with temporary shows
Of lives connected, yet alone.

The darkness parts before our metal flight,
Then closes gently in our wake.
We dart between the stations of the night,
Leaving nothing but ripples in our make.

IRON TRAJECTORY

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
Slicing night's fabric with determined steel.
A mechanical prophecy, forever starting,
Imprinting motion on what we feel.

The carriage rocks with gentle insistence,
Cradling travelers in its metal embrace.
We measure progress not in distance,
But in the transformation of space.

Outside, the world is reduced to streaks—
Farm lights like fireflies quickly gone,
Mountains to shadows, rivers to creeks,
All reality distilled, withdrawn.

I wonder about the hands that laid these tracks,
Their labor now enabling flight.
How many journeys, departures, and backs?
How many arrows shot through night?

We dart forward on determined course,
Neither fully here nor there—
Suspended between origin and source,
Piercing darkness without care.

MIDNIGHT EXPRESS

VELOCITY

The countryside sleeps under indigo blankets

Outside: black mirror reflecting our faces,

We are all arrows shot from different bows,

The train whistle cries—a primal yearning—

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,

PASSAGE

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,

Outside, the world rushes by in fragments:

We passengers, momentary companions,

Perhaps the knowledge that we all must roam.

The windows frame the darkness like a painting

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,

Nothing is quite as permanent as it seems.

We passengers sit in our separate silences,
Strangers united by parallel flight.
Hurtling toward dawn with blind conviction,
Trusting steel and steam to guide us through night.

VELOCITY

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
Piercing the membrane between here and there.
Its metal body vibrates with purpose,
Cutting through silence with industrial prayer.

Inside, we rock like infants in cradles,
Lulled by the rhythm of distance consumed.
Outside, the world dissolves into streaking lights,
Geographies compressed, landscapes entombed.

I press my forehead against cool glass,
Watching my reflection fragment and fade.
We are all just passengers in transit,
Seeking connections that time has delayed.

The train barrels forward with blind conviction,
Its trajectory set before we stepped aboard.
We surrender to its determined motion,
Our destinations already explored.

NOCTURNAL TRAJECTORY

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
A constellation of lighted windows strung
Across the obsidian canvas of night.
Its determined path unwavering, certain.

I count the telegraph poles as they vanish,
Ghostly sentinels marking our flight.
The rhythm of wheels against steel rails
Composes a lullaby of mechanical might.

We passengers drift between worlds,
Neither here nor there—suspended in transit.
Our stories intersecting briefly,
Before diverging at platforms distant.

The countryside sleeps as we pass through,
Dreams disturbed by our thunderous passing.
Yet we carry on, relentless in motion,
Time itself bending to our unceasing asking.

IRON TRAJECTORY

Like a long arrow through the dark the train is darting,
A needle threading night's expansive cloth.
Carrying dreamers, seekers, and the heartbroken,
All bound by motion's unrelenting froth.

The engine pulls us through tunnels of shadow,
Its determined heart beating diesel and steam.
We surrender to its forward momentum,
Caught between memory and distant dream.

Stars wheel overhead in cosmic indifference,
As towns appear then disappear from view.
Each station a brief respite from journey,
A momentary pause before beginning anew.

I trace condensation paths on window glass,
Mapping routes I'll never truly take.
While beneath my feet, the steady rhythm
Remains constant, even as the dawn breaks.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I cry, but the tears dont even stay by my side.'

responses.text:
# Abandoned by Tears

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They abandon me like fair-weather friends,
Evaporating into the atmosphere of my despair,
Leaving me parched in my own sorrow.

Even my grief refuses to linger,
Slipping through fingers that grasp at emotion.
My sadness, too liquid to hold,
Too fleeting to prove I ever felt anything at all.

The evidence of my pain disappears
Faster than the memory of your touch.
Am I so hollow that even my suffering
Cannot bear to dwell within me?

I am a desert of feeling,
Where droplets of anguish evaporate
Before they can nurture even the smallest bloom
Of healing or closure.

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side—
The ultimate betrayal: abandoned
Even by the physical proof
Of my breaking heart.

# Ephemeral Mourning

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They race down cheeks flushed with grief,
Dissipating into nothingness—
Like promises you once whispered.

They fall to the ground, these liquid traitors,
Merging with earth and forgotten rain.
No evidence remains of my sorrow;
Even my pain refuses to be documented.

How strange to feel so much
Yet hold so little proof.
My body creates these silver messengers
Only to send them away immediately.

Perhaps tears know better than to linger
In the wasteland of what once was.
They flee from memory's sharp edges,
Wiser than I could ever hope to be.

So I stand, face dry in moments,
Though oceans rage within.
A paradox of emptiness and fullness—
A heart drowning while skin remains desert-dry.

# Liquid Desertion

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They choose gravity over loyalty,
Falling from my face like stars
Descending from a collapsing universe.

My own body betrays me;
Creating witnesses to my pain
Only to dismiss them immediately—
A courtroom where evidence evaporates.

Each droplet carries fragments
Of a heart too heavy to hold together.
Yet they disappear so quickly,
As if ashamed of their origin.

What remains when even manifestations
Of sorrow refuse to linger?
A face too quickly dried,
Hiding the storm that rages within.

Perhaps I should thank these deserters
For their swift departure—
For leaving no salt-stained trails
On skin that pretends to have never known grief.

# Drought of Witness

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They vanish like morning dew under harsh sun,
Leaving no evidence of the night's despair,
No testament to the breaking within.

How lonely to watch your own sorrow
Abandon you before it's fully expressed.
Even the water from my eyes
Hurries away, embarrassed by my weakness.

I search for proof that I have felt—
Damp sleeves, wet pillows, something tangible—
But find only the ghost of emotion,
The afterimage of grief already fading.

Perhaps this is mercy:
The swift erasure of visible pain.
Yet I long for the comfort of witnessed sorrow,
The validation of tears that remain.

So I stand in this drought of compassion,
Even my own body refusing to acknowledge
The storms that rage beneath the surface,
The floods contained by fragile banks of skin.

# Unwitnessed Sorrow

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They flee like frightened children
From a home no longer safe,
Leaving me alone with hollow echoes.

What use is this saltwater rebellion
That refuses to document my undoing?
Each droplet—a potential witness—
Evaporates before testimony can be given.

The world demands evidence of suffering
Yet my body conspires against me,
Producing proof that self-destructs,
Leaving grief invisible to all but me.

Perhaps there is wisdom in their escape;
They know this sadness is too vast
To be contained in such small vessels,
Too profound to be measured in drops.

So I stand with dry face and drenched soul,
A walking contradiction of appearance and reality.
A desert on the surface
With oceans raging underneath.

responses.text:
# Abandoned Tears

# Ephemeral Mourning

That even grief must eventually surrender
To gravity's insistent pull.

I envy their freedom, these droplets of sorrow,
Their journey complete in moments,
While I remain tethered to this aching,
Unable to follow their swift release.

So I will learn from my tears' wisdom:
To express and then let go,
To allow pain its momentary presence
Before releasing it back to the universe.

# Liquid Deserters

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
Fickle companions of my deepest despair,
They materialize only to vanish,
Temporary witnesses to an eternal wound.

How strange to birth something from your own body
That so quickly seeks escape,
As if my sadness is too heavy a burden
Even for the very manifestations it creates.

I watch them fall, these crystal betrayers,
Splashing against whatever lies below,
Diluting themselves into oblivion
While my pain remains concentrated, pure.

Perhaps there's wisdom in their hasty departure—
A lesson in impermanence written in salt and water.
Why should they linger when nothing else does?
When love, joy, and hope have all fled before them?

So I'll stop trying to hold what wants to leave,
And instead marvel at how even in abandonment,
There is a kind of freedom to be found
In watching what's mine become not-mine.

# The Mathematics of Grief

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
Subtraction upon subtraction—
First you left, then my dignity,
Now even the salt-water proof of my grieving
Has calculated its own escape velocity.

What remains when everything subtracts itself?
A negative space where positives once lived,
An equation unbalanced by loss,
A remainder that refuses to be resolved.

Gravity, that most loyal of forces,
Becomes conspirator to my abandonment,
Pulling each droplet away from its source,
Teaching me that even physics favors separation.

I wonder if tears evaporate or simply transform,
Becoming the clouds that will rain on someone else's day.
Perhaps my sorrow waters distant gardens,
Nourishing strangers with what I couldn't keep.

So I'll continue this algebra of absence,
Subtracting what won't stay, adding what I can bear,
Multiplying my resilience, dividing my expectations,
Until I solve for x: the unknown variable of peace.

# Drought of Companionship

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side.
They rush to join the earth, the air, anything but me—
As if my company is something to escape,
As if my sorrow is contagious.

Even these liquid pieces of myself
Seek freedom from their creator,
Leaving nothing but dry trails
And the memory of momentary wetness.

I've become a desert of abandonment,
Where not even the rain of my own making
Will saturate this parched landscape,
These cracked plains of my heart.

Perhaps there's a strange mercy in their leaving—
If they lingered, wouldn't I drown?
If my grief remained visible,
Wouldn't I be forced to face it endlessly?

So I'll thank these deserting droplets
For teaching me the art of letting go,
For showing me that even the most intimate expressions
Must eventually find their own path home.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I Hunted Words Of Skill'

responses.text:
I Hunted Words Of Skill

With quiver full of questions,
I stalked through forests of thought,
Tracking elusive phrases
That wiser minds had wrought.

My fingers, nimble arrows,
Drew back on wisdom's bow,
Releasing into parchment
The truths I came to know.

Some words fled like shadows,
Others stood proud as stags,
Defiant in their meaning,
Unfurling mental flags.

I gathered them like trophies,
These syllables of might,
Strung them on necklaces of verse
That shimmer in the light.

The hunt goes ever onward,
Through valleys deep with lore,
For words, once caught, breed questions
That beg for hunting more.

THE LEXICAL HUNTER

I hunted words of skill across barren plains of page,
Armed with nothing but desire and the hunger of my age.
Footprints of poets before me, fading in the dust,
Guided my expedition—this search, a sacred trust.

Through thickets of metaphor, I crawled on bloodied knees,
Snaring similes that fluttered like wounded birds through trees.
I laid traps of patience where inspiration flows,
And waited in the silence that only seeker knows.

Some nights yielded nothing but the howling of my doubt,
Other dawns broke golden with phrases turned inside out.
I skinned each captured concept, preserved its beating heart,
Mounted trophy sentences—a gallery of art.

Now my walls are decorated with linguistic heads,
Stuffed and mounted memories of all that's done and said.
Yet still I hunt at midnight, my quill a ready spear,
For words of skill worth hunting never truly disappear.

WORDSMITH'S PURSUIT

I hunted words of skill
Through dictionaries vast and still,
While midnight oil burned low and thin,
And stars collapsed their light within.

Each syllable a precious gem,
Some rough-hewn, some diadem,
I sifted through linguistic sand
For gold no other would demand.

The chase led down forgotten paths
Where ancient tongues survived time's wraths,
And in the spaces between thought,
I found the treasures that I sought.

Some words fought back with teeth and claw,
Resisted capture, wild and raw,
While others came with gentle ease,
Like autumn leaves on morning breeze.

Now strung together, pearls on string,
They form a song that I might sing,
A testament to patient hunt
Where meaning rises from the front.

Still searching, always, for the phrase
That perfectly captures life's maze—
The hunt itself becomes the skill
That feeds the hunger, never still.

VERBAL EXPEDITION

I hunted words of skill
Across parchment plains untilled,
Armed with ink-stained fingers,
And thoughts that burned and thrilled.

Each phrase a wary creature
Dancing just beyond my reach,
Elusive in its beauty,
A lesson it would teach.

Some words were swift as swallows,
Others, stubborn as stone,
I tracked them through the shadows
Of meanings overgrown.

My traps were set with questions,
My snares with wonder laid,
I caught the wild conjunctions
Where grammar rules had frayed.

At dusk I'd count my captures,
Arrange them line by line,
Discovering in their patterns
A wilderness divine.

The hunt has changed the hunter—
I am the prey, the skill;
The words I thought I hunted
Have claimed me, haunt me still.

LEXICAL SAFARI

I hunted words of skill
With nets of consciousness,
Trekking through mental jungles
Of tangled wilderness.

The rare ones hide in shadows
Of thoughts not yet conceived,
Camouflaged in silence,
In moments unperceived.

I've stalked the verb that captures
The essence of a dream,
And tracked elusive nouns that
Are never what they seem.

Adjectives, like plumage,
Attract with vibrant hue,
But catch them in wrong seasons—
Their meanings ring untrue.

The adverbs run in packs,
Modifying as they race
Across the mind's savannah,
Leaving tracks I must retrace.

My trophy case stands empty,
Though hunts have numbered years.
For words of skill, once captured,
Transform the one who hears.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She lies alone upon her bed'

responses.text:
She lies alone upon her bed,
A desert island in a sea of night,
Where whispered dreams and shadows tread
Across the ceiling's pale moonlight.

The clock ticks forward, never back,
A metronome of passing time,
While memories fill the quiet lack
Of voices, touch, of reason, rhyme.

The pillow bears the weight of tears
Unspilled, held back by pride and will,
A silent witness to the years
Of longing that she carries still.

Her fingers trace the empty space
Where once another's warmth would rest,
The phantom touch, the absent grace
Of love that once her heart possessed.

She lies alone, but is not lost,
For in her solitude she finds
A strength that comes at bitter cost—
The peace that solitary binds.

She lies alone upon her bed
Like autumn leaves adrift in air,
A tapestry of thoughts unsaid
Entwined within her copper hair.

The ceiling fan spins tales above
Of journeys to far distant shores,
Where she could taste the salt of love
And walk through undiscovered doors.

The world outside continues on,
A symphony of noise and light,
While she remains, a faded swan,
Immersed in pools of quiet night.

What visions dance behind closed eyes?
What universes does she build?
Perhaps she soars through azure skies
Or walks through fields with wildflowers filled.

For solitude is not a cage
But canvas for the dreaming mind,
Where she can write her hidden page
And leave reality behind.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A warrior laid down to rest,
The battle scars invisible
Beneath her rising, falling chest.

The day has drained her vibrant hues,
Left watercolors, pale and thin,
The world demands so much of her—
To bend, not break; to lose, yet win.

The ceiling holds her gaze like faith,
A blank projection of her mind,
Where worries bloom like midnight flowers
And doubts like shadows intertwined.

Her fingertips drum silent songs
Against the fabric of her sheets,
A morse code meant for no one's ears,
A rhythm only she repeats.

Tomorrow waits beyond the dawn,
Another chance to rise anew,
For now, this solitude's her strength—
This quiet space to breathe into.

She lies alone upon her bed
A constellation of herself,
Fragmented stars of who she was
And who she yearns to be.

The walls around her listen close
To breaths that rise and fall like tides,
Each inhale drawing in the world,
Each exhale setting sorrows free.

The phone lies silent by her side,
A portal closed to other lives,
While hers unfolds in quiet ways,
A story told in whispered sighs.

What magic brews within her mind
As twilight deepens into night?
What alchemy transforms her thoughts
To golden dreams and silver flight?

She lies alone, yet not alone—
For in this sacred, private space,
She meets herself without disguise
And holds her truth in warm embrace.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A shipwreck on a cotton sea,
The navigator of her dreams
Set temporarily free.

The world has turned its back on day,
Embraced the moon's enchanted light,
While she, suspended in between,
Drifts slowly through the velvet night.

The ghosts of conversations past
Still echo in her restless mind,
The words she spoke, the ones unsaid,
The truths she sought but could not find.

Her fingers clutch the rumpled sheets,
An anchor to this present hour,
While thoughts like petals scatter wide—
Some bitter, some as sweet as flower.

She lies alone, but in this space
Between the darkness and the dawn,
She crafts herself from stardust dreams
And waits for light to carry on.

For weathering tomorrow's storms.

She lies alone upon her bed
Not abandoned, but complete
A universe contained in skin
A goddess resting, bittersweet.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A book of stories left unread,
The chapters of her yesterday
Fold gently as she slips away.

The ceiling holds her questions high,
Like constellations in the sky,
Connecting dots of what's to come,
Of who she was and will become.

The window frames the passing clouds,
As time moves on without a sound,
Her breath in rhythm with the night,
A peaceful surrender without fight.

She lies alone, but not apart,
From all that lives within her heart,
For solitude has taught her this:
In being alone, there's also bliss.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She lies alone upon her bed'

responses.text:
She lies alone upon her bed,
Staring at shadows on the wall,
Memories like ghosts in her head,
Whispering of times beyond recall.

The sheets, cold against her skin,
Bear witness to her silent tears,
As moonlight filters slowly in,
Illuminating all her fears.

Once two hearts beat in this room,
Now only echoes of what was,
Loneliness blooms like winter's bloom,
A garden of thorns, because

She lies alone upon her bed,
Clutching letters never sent,
Words of love remain unsaid,
In the hollow of abandonment.

Yet morning will come, as it must,
Bringing courage with the light,
From solitude to hope and trust,
She'll rise again and win the fight.

She lies alone upon her bed
A universe contained in bone and breath
A constellation of thoughts unsaid
Dancing between life and death

Her fingers trace invisible maps
Across the ceiling's blank expanse
While time around her gently laps
Like waves in cosmic dance

The world outside continues on
Unaware of her private galaxy
The stars she's gathered since the dawn
Of her quiet reality

Is she prisoner or is she free?
In this sanctuary of cotton and down
Where dreams and nightmares come to be
Where crowns are lost and found

She lies alone upon her bed
A poem writing itself into being
Neither fully alive nor dead
But perfectly, completely, seeing.

She lies alone upon her bed
Not in sorrow, but in flight
For though her body rests its head
Her mind soars through the night

The ceiling fades to open sky
As constellations bloom and bend
She charts new worlds with inner eye
Where broken things may mend

No company but books well-loved
Their spines like friends along the wall
Their wisdom like the stars above
Answering her silent call

The clock ticks on, but time's suspended
In this chamber of her making
Where solitude is not lamented
But celebrated in the taking

She lies alone upon her bed
A universe unto herself
Not abandoned, but instead
Discovering her truest wealth.

She lies alone upon her bed
Like driftwood on a distant shore
The hurricane of life has fled
Leaving her hollow to the core

The ceiling fan spins tales above
Of moments lost to yesterday
Of whispered words and faded love
Of souls that couldn't stay

Her phone lies dark beside her hand
No messages to break the spell
Of isolation's barren land
Where echoes of her heartbeats dwell

The city hums beyond her walls
A symphony she cannot join
As twilight slowly falls
And darkness starts to coin

Its currency of stars and dreams
She trades her tears for silver light
And in this exchange, it seems
She finds her strength to face the night.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A warrior resting from the fray,
The battle scars inside her head
Will heal another day.

The armor shed, her shield laid down,
No weapon needed in this space,
No kingdom lost, no stolen crown,
Just quiet, time, and grace.

The world demanded everything—
Her smile, her strength, her very soul.
Now silence is the only thing
That makes her broken pieces whole.

The solitude, once feared, now friend,
Embraces her with gentle arms.
This sacred time, a chance to mend
Away from all alarms.

She lies alone upon her bed,
Not lonely, but complete at last.
The chaos of the day has fled.
The future, present, and the past
Merge softly as she breathes and rests,
At peace within her sovereign breast.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She lies alone upon her bed'

responses.text:
She lies alone upon her bed,
A canvas of thoughts stretched in her head.
Memories dance like shadows on the wall,
Whispering tales of summer and fall.

The weight of silence presses down,
In this empty room where echoes drown.
Fingers trace the vacant space beside,
Where once another's warmth would reside.

Moonlight streams through parted curtain,
Illuminating questions, nothing certain.
The clock ticks forward, relentless, slow,
Marking time as emotions ebb and flow.

She crafts dreams from scattered stars,
Rebuild galaxies from ancient scars.
Alone yet complete in her solitude,
A universe contained in quietude.

She lies alone upon her bed,
While thunder clouds gather overhead.
Her fingers clutch at cotton sheets,
As her wild heart erratically beats.

The room grows colder with the night,
As she surrenders without a fight.
To memories that refuse to fade,
Of promises that were betrayed.

The mirror across reflects a stranger's face,
A woman lost in time and space.
She counts the cracks along the wall,
Waiting for sleep to finally call.

Morning will come with merciful light,
Erasing shadows of this endless night.
She lies alone, but tomorrow brings
The strength to spread her broken wings.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A garden of books blooms around her head.
Worlds unfold between pages worn,
Characters breathe as new days are born.

Ink-stained fingers trace ancient lore,
Mind wandering to distant shore.
Solitude chosen, not imposed,
In literary embrace, fully enclosed.

The ceiling transforms to midnight sky,
As dragons and spaceships go sailing by.
Alone in body but not in mind,
Companionship in stories she finds.

Laughter escapes into empty air,
At adventures with friends who aren't there.
She lies alone upon her bed,
But travels universes instead.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A warrior queen with battle-weary head.
The day's armor finally shed,
Vulnerable now in twilight spread.

Her kingdom waits beyond these walls,
Responsibilities and duty calls.
But in darkness, crown set aside,
No subjects witness how she's cried.

The strength that others always see,
Melts into quiet fragility.
Pillows catch whispered doubts and fears,
Absorb the weight of unshed tears.

Yet dawn will find her standing tall,
Ready again to face it all.
She lies alone to rest and mend,
So tomorrow she can rise and transcend.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A symphony of silence fills her head.
The city hums beyond her window pane,
A chorus distant as falling rain.

Time suspended in the in-between,
Neither awake nor lost in dream.
The ceiling's blank canvas overhead,
Bears projections of words unsaid.

She's an island in a rumpled sea,
Adrift in thoughts of what could be.
Fingers trace patterns on cotton shore,
Mapping journeys to distant lore.

The universe expands and contracts,
With every breath her body acts.
She lies alone—complete, contained—
In solitude, herself reclaimed.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She lies alone upon her bed'

responses.text:
She lies alone upon her bed,
A canvas of moonlight on her face,
Thoughts like autumn leaves scatter,
Dancing through memories of grace.

Fingers trace the empty space beside,
Where warmth once nestled near,
The silence speaks in volumes now,
A language crystal clear.

Dreams float like dandelion seeds,
Carried by night's gentle breeze,
To distant shores of might-have-beens,
And oceans of possibilities.

The clock ticks forward, never back,
A faithful keeper of the night,
As she lies alone upon her bed,
Bathed in silver starlight bright.

In solitude she finds her strength,
In quiet moments, truth revealed,
She lies alone upon her bed,
But in her heart, she's never sealed.

She lies alone upon her bed
A sentinel of forgotten wars
The ceiling's cracks map territories
Of battles fought behind closed doors

The fan above whirs conspiracies
Of words she should have said instead
Her phone lies dark beside her hand
A bridge to voices long since fled

The walls lean in to hear her breathe
The rhythm of her quiet despair
As shadows dance across her form
Like memories she cannot bear

She counts the hours till dawn will break
And she can wear her armor again
For in daylight she's invincible
It's only night that brings the pain

She lies alone upon her bed
A universe contained in skin
The strongest when most vulnerable
As sleep finally welcomes her in

She lies alone upon her bed,
A constellation of freckles and scars,
Each telling stories of mountains climbed,
Of valleys crossed and reaching for stars.

The quilt, her grandmother's final gift,
Wraps around her like yesterday's prayer,
While outside her window, city lights
Compete with heaven's celestial flare.

Her books stand guard on weathered shelves,
Spines cracked from journeys often taken,
To worlds where heroes never yield
And faith remains forever unshaken.

She dreams not of princes or castles grand
But of forests wild and oceans deep,
Of writing her name across the sky
With promises she intends to keep.

She lies alone upon her bed,
But solitude is not loneliness here—
It's freedom's canvas, wide and blank,
Where tomorrow's colors will appear.

She lies alone upon her bed
With fever dreams that twist and turn,
The illness grips her fragile frame
As candles by the window burn.

The doctor's words still echo loud
Like thunder in a cloudless sky,
Six months, perhaps a year at most,
Too young, too soon, to say goodbye.

Her children's laughter from the yard
Floats upward through the open pane,
A melody she tries to store
Against the coming nights of pain.

She counts each breath as precious gold,
Each sunrise as a gift divine,
The simplest pleasures magnified
When measured on mortality's line.

She lies alone upon her bed,
Yet feels the universe expand,
Within the confines of her room,
Eternity held in her hand.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A voyager between two worlds,
Neither fully here nor there—
A flag of surrender half-unfurled.

The medication bottles stand
Like sentries on her nightstand post,
While monitors beep steady rhythms,
Her heart's persistent, stubborn boast.

The walls of white, institutional,
Cannot contain her wandering mind,
That flies beyond this sterile room
To meadows she may never find.

Visitors come with plastic smiles,
And words that stumble, trip, and fall,
While she drifts further from their reach
Beyond the hospital's cold wall.

She lies alone upon her bed,
A chrysalis in slow transform,
Neither broken nor yet healed,
A soul caught in transition's storm.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Per me si va nella citta dolente.'

responses.text:
Through me the way into the city of sorrow,
Where ancient whispers echo through the night,
Where souls abandoned hope for tomorrow,
And darkness reigns where once there was light.

I stand before these gates of weathered stone,
Inscribed with warnings from a time long past,
A threshold crossed by those who walk alone,
Into the depths where shadows have been cast.

Like Dante's pilgrim on his sacred quest,
I hesitate before this daunting door,
My heart beats wildly in my trembling chest,
As I contemplate what might lie in store.

For in this city, pain has found its home,
Where tears flow freely down the cobbled streets,
Where broken spirits endlessly do roam,
And time stretches on in endless repeats.

Yet even in this place of endless night,
Perhaps a spark of beauty still remains,
A lesson hidden in the absence of light,
A wisdom born of suffering and pains.

DOLENTE

Through me one enters the sorrowful city—
words carved in stone above an archway
leading to narrow streets I never meant to walk.
The language of another world, another time,
yet somehow I understand its weight.

I have built my own cities of sorrow,
bricked them carefully with regrets,
paved their roads with choices
I cannot unmake. Each window
shuttered against light I once craved.

How easily we become architects
of our own suffering, engineers
of labyrinths we later cannot escape.
Dante knew this when he penned his journey—
how hell is not a place but a perspective.

I stand at the threshold of my creation,
tracing the inscription with trembling fingers.
Per me si va nella città dolente.
Through me. Through me. As if the entrance
itself could speak, could warn, could absolve.

Perhaps today I will not enter.
Perhaps today I will turn away,
and build instead a city of mercy,
where grace flows through the streets
like a river that remembers the sea.

PASSAGE

Through me one enters the grieving city—
these words, not mine, but borrowed
from a poet who walked through hell
and lived to tell of what he'd seen.

I too have stood at thresholds
of cities built from pain,
their architecture intricate with loss,
their citizens the ghosts of former selves.

What courage it must take
to step beyond the gate, knowing
what waits within cannot be undone—
the witnessing, the recognition, the truth.

In my own language, I lack the words
for what Dante named so precisely:
la città dolente—where sorrow
is not emotion but location, not passing but permanent.

Yet I have lived there too, in rooms
where grief hung heavy as incense,
in streets where memories ambushed me
at every corner, every familiar turn.

Per me si va—through me the way—
as if the entrance itself had agency,
as if the door could speak, could say:
I am both warning and invitation.

And we, the living, pause before such passages,
knowing some crossings change us forever.

THE DESCENT

Through me lies the path to the grieving city,
Where shadows dance on walls of ancient stone.
I stand before these gates, my heart grown gritty
With dust from roads too long traveled alone.

What Dante saw beyond this dark threshold,
I too have glimpsed in dreams and waking hours—
The landscapes of a pain that grows old
But never dies, just withers like cut flowers.

The language of his warning feels like home,
These foreign words more native than my own.
Per me si va—through me—we come to roam
The labyrinth where nothing is unknown.

Each person carries cities in their chest,
Geographies of joy and of despair.
Some chambers we display to honored guests,
While others hide what we can scarcely bear.

I trace these words etched deep in memory's wall,
And wonder if all entries are returns.
If every city dolente is a call
To recognize the space where sorrow burns.

Perhaps in naming it, as Dante did,
We find the courage finally to depart,
To leave behind the grief we've long forbid
Ourselves to feel, to heal the broken heart.

INFERNO'S ECHO

Through me the way into the suffering city,
Dante's words echo across centuries,
A warning carved in language rich and gritty,
A threshold marking fate's severe decrees.

I've never walked the streets of Florence, yet
I understand this passage all too well—
The gateway to a place we can't forget,
A personal, a private kind of hell.

How strange that words from medieval verse
Can capture modern anguish, modern pain.
Some doorways, once we cross, become a curse,
Some knowledge, once acquired, will remain.

La città dolente—the grieving town—
Exists not just in poetry or dreams,
But in the heart when walls come crashing down,
When nothing is exactly as it seems.

I stand before my own infernal gate,
The entrance to what I must face alone.
Some journeys we can neither flee nor wait,
Some paths are paved with more than just stone.

Per me si va—through me you go—it states,
As if the passage itself has found voice.
How curious that language contemplates
The threshold as possessing will, not choice.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Per me si va nella citta dolente.'

responses.text:
Through me, the path to the grieving city lies,
Where souls in torment weep beneath dark skies.
Dante's words echo through centuries old,
As I stand at the threshold, trembling yet bold.

The gates of sorrow creak on rusted hinge,
Inviting steps where angels fear to tinge.
What lies beyond this entrance to despair?
A landscape painted with the brush of nightmare.

Yet in this darkness, truth reveals its face,
For only through descent can we embrace
The shadow-self we desperately deny.
To know true joy, we must first learn to cry.

So forward now, into the city's heart,
Where pain and wisdom are not far apart.
Through suffering streets and alleys lined with tears,
I'll walk until the morning light appears.

DOLENTE

Through me one enters the sorrowful city,
Words carved in stone above hellish gates.
I trace these letters with trembling fingers,
A tourist in grief's ancient landscape.

What cities have I built from my own sorrows?
What populations inhabit my private inferno?
Streets paved with regrets, buildings constructed
From the architecture of abandoned dreams.

The dolente within me grows vast and sprawling,
A metropolis of memories better forgotten.
Each citizen bears my face, yet twisted
By the particular anguish that claimed them.

I have become both traveler and destination,
Guide and lost soul, architect and ruin.
Dante knew this paradox—to map hell
One must first recognize it as home.

Through me one enters the sorrowful city.
Through me, one finally learns the way out.

PASSAGE

Through me the way into the city of sorrow—
I whisper this to myself on ordinary Tuesday mornings
when the coffee tastes of nothing
and the mirror shows a stranger's face.

What dolente waits beyond today's threshold?
What grief-streets must I wander before sunset?
Each doorway promises its own specific anguish;
each window frames a different shade of loss.

Dante knew of circles, neat divisions
for categorizing pain. But my city
has no maps, no guides, no ordered rings—
just endless boulevards that circle back

to where I started. In this labyrinth
of heartache, I have learned to leave
small markers: a remembered joy,
a moment's kindness, unexpected beauty

glimmering like coins dropped by fellow travelers.
Through me, the passage into suffering.
Through me, perhaps, someday,
the undiscovered exit leading home.

INFERNAL CARTOGRAPHY

I trace the words upon my palm:
'Through me the way to the city of sorrows.'
Dante's warning becomes my invitation,
a map to territories I already inhabit.

The city dolente has no fixed address.
Some days it rises in my chest,
a metropolis of thorns and whispers.
Other days, I glimpse it in strangers' eyes,

in the slump of shoulders on subway cars,
in headlines that make us look away.
We are all cartographers of suffering,
each plotting different routes through identical pain.

What would Virgil guide me toward today?
Perhaps the circle where old lovers burn
in flames of their own making. Or where
the indifferent freeze in ice of their creation.

I have no golden bough, no poet's grace,
only these words I scratch against the darkness.
Through me, through you, through everyone—
the mournful city opens countless doors.

THROUGH ME

Through me lies the path to the grieving city—
not Rome or Florence or Milan,
but that interior landscape we each carry,
where sorrows collect like rain in ancient cisterns.

I've wandered those narrow streets at midnight,
traced my fingers along walls built from memories
that cut like broken glass. I've heard the whispers
of regrets that nest in shadowed doorways.

Dante knew this geography of anguish,
mapped its circles, named its demons,
braved its depths to find his way toward stars.
But what was his dolente compared to ours?

We've built more sophisticated hells
since his medieval imagination.
Our cities of sorrow feature digital torments,
global warming, extinction's quiet approach.

Yet still we seek the path that leads beyond grief.
Through me, through you, through words themselves—
we forge the passages that might, with courage,
deliver us into unexpected light.

URBAN INFERNO

TRANSLATIONS

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Per me si va nella citta dolente.'

responses.text:
Through Me to the City of Sorrow

Through me to the city of sorrow,

I stand before these gates of dread,

Yet even in this realm of night,

I search for some forgotten light,

For in the city's doleful song,
I hear my own heart's hidden cries,
The weight of choices right and wrong,
The truth no mortal can disguise.

Through me, through you, through all who weep,
The path to sorrow opens wide,
But even in its chasms deep,
Some spark of grace might still abide.

Infernal Gates

Per me si va nella citta dolente—
Through me one enters suffering's domain,
Ancient words carved on gates I cannot see
Yet feel their weight upon my soul like rain.

I wander streets of modern desolation,
No Virgil guides me through this concrete hell,
Only the whispers of my own creation,
And memories too stubborn to dispel.

Each circle deeper than the one before,
Each sin more recognizable than last,
I navigate this labyrinth of lore
Where present anguish mirrors shadows past.

What city calls with such a doleful voice?
Is it not built within these bones of mine?
Constructed slowly, choice by painful choice,
A private inferno, uniquely designed.

Yet through these gates, perhaps a path remains
To climb from darkness toward some distant star,
For even Dante, witnessing all pains,
Emerged to tell us what we truly are.

The Sorrowful City

Through me lies the path to the sorrowful city,
Words etched in stone by a poet's hand.
I trace each letter, feeling neither pity
Nor fear, just wonder at what they command.

What doleful cities do we build today?
Towers of glass reflecting empty eyes,
Streets where we pass but never truly stay,
Where sirens wail beneath indifferent skies.

Perhaps the gates to Hell aren't grand at all,
But ordinary doorways we walk through
When we choose hate instead of love's sweet call,
Or turn from what we know is right and true.

I've wandered lost in my own city of pain,
Constructed from regrets and might-have-beens,
Where memories fall like unrelenting rain
On monuments to all my secret sins.

Yet even in this doleful place I've found
That suffering can be a sacred space,
Where wisdom grows from grief in hallowed ground,
And sorrow transforms into gentle grace.

Descent

Through me one goes into the city of woe—
I whisper these words as I stand at the edge,
Not of Dante's Hell with its circles below,
But the precipice of my own soul's dark ledge.

The city of sorrow has no fixed address,
It dwells in the spaces between heartbeats and breath,
In moments of silence we try to suppress,
In questions that haunt us of life and of death.

I've built my own Inferno, brick by brick,
With walls of denial and towers of shame,
A labyrinth where lost thoughts gather thick,
Where I am both prisoner and judge without name.

What strange comfort in these ancient words I find,
That even the greatest minds knew this descent,
That suffering has always been intertwined
With being human—this shared punishment.

Per me si va—through me the way appears.
Perhaps in acknowledging the path to pain,
We finally face our most primeval fears,
And walking through sorrow, emerge whole again.

Eternal Transit

'Per me si va nella citta dolente.'
The words echo across centuries of dust.
I stand at my own gateway, heaven-sent,
Facing passages I travel because I must.

No Virgil guides me through these modern hells,
No poet's hand to steady trembling doubt.
Just ordinary demons, common spells,
The daily infernos we speak nothing about.

What cities of sorrow have we constructed?
Skyscrapers of ambition, streets of regret,
Subways of longing where souls are conducted
To destinations they struggle to forget.

I trace the inscription with my fingertips,
Not carved in stone but written in my veins.
The ancient warning on Florentine lips
Still resonates through contemporary pains.

Perhaps all journeys lead through suffering's gate,
Perhaps all wisdom comes from this descent.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Per me si va nella citta dolente.'

responses.text:

CITY OF SORROWS

PASSAGE

Through me one journeys to the grieving town,

INFERNAL CARTOGRAPHY

that led through circles spiraling toward pain.

where joy seems just a theory, not a truth.

where humans gather, build, and then destroy.
It stands invisible beside our homes,
a parallel dimension made of tears.

Yet even in this shadow territory,
where sorrow's architecture blocks the sun,
I've witnessed strangers offer up their hands
to pull the fallen back onto their feet.

Perhaps the path that leads to suffering
also reveals the road that leads us out.

THE DESCENT

Through me one journeys to the city of grief—
Italian words that haunt my waking dreams.
I never thought such darkness would be mine,
Yet here I stand at sorrow's precipice.

The city dolent waits with open arms,
A lover scorned yet eager to embrace.
Its streets are paved with broken promises,
Its buildings made of fossilized regret.

I did not choose this pilgrimage of pain,
This slow descent through circles of despair.
No Virgil guides my trembling, faltering steps,
No poet's wisdom lights the darkened way.

Yet something calls from deep within that place—
Perhaps the voice of others who have walked
These same forbidden paths and somehow found
That suffering transformed becomes a gift.

I enter now. The gates close at my back.
Through me, through pain, a new world may emerge.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Per me si va nella citta dolente.'

responses.text:
Through me one enters the city of sorrow,
Where ancient words echo Dante's despair.
I stand at the threshold of tomorrow,
Whispers of lost souls fill the air.

The gates of anguish creak and moan,
As I trace paths through shadowed stone.

In this realm where all must grieve.

Yet in darkness, strange beauty blooms—
Like flowers growing between the tombs.
For in suffering we find our truth,
The wisdom that eludes our youth.

Through me the city dolente calls,
Its siren song behind crumbling walls.
I enter willingly, eyes wide open,
To find what lessons pain has woken.

DOLENTE

Through me lies the city of lament
Where teardrops crystallize on cobblestone streets
And memories hang like tattered flags
From windows that no longer open.

I walked there once, barefoot and trembling,
Following the trail of discarded dreams
That spiraled downward, ever downward
Into chambers where regret ferments.

The citizens wear masks of normalcy
But their eyes betray centuries of grief.
They serve me coffee in chipped porcelain,
Their hands steady despite the weight they bear.

In the dolente city, music still plays—
Mournful violins that scrape against the soul.
I listen, and find myself humming along,
Surprised to discover I knew the tune all along.

INFERNAL PASSAGE

Through me one journeys to the grieving city,
Where stars refuse to shine their distant light.
The entrance stands, both terrible and pretty,
A threshold between comfort and eternal night.

I trace the words carved deep in ancient stone,
And feel their warning tremble in my chest.
This path was never meant to walk alone,
Yet solitude becomes my faithful guest.

The city dolente breathes with memories
Of choices made when crossroads came to call.
Its architecture built from histories
Of those who climbed before their fatal fall.

Perhaps this journey leads not just to pain,
But understanding of what lies beyond.
For in the suffering, we might attain
A wisdom that the sheltered never found.

THROUGH ME

Through me one enters the city of woe—
Not built of stone but of remembered pain,
Its boulevards paved with what we cannot let go,
Its fountains flowing with unspoken shame.

I did not choose to be this gateway dark,
This passage to a landscape of despair.
Yet on my soul these words have left their mark:
"Per me si va"—through me, you enter there.

The citizens move slowly through the squares,
Their faces mirrors of my own regret.
They carry burdens heavier than theirs,
Debts of the heart they never can forget.

Yet strangely, in this dolente place,
A certain beauty haunts the shadowed streets.
For truth resides in sorrow's fierce embrace,
And in surrender, wisdom finds its seat.

THE SORROWFUL PASSAGE

Through me the pathway to the city weeping,
Where shadows dance on walls of cold despair.
Not all who wander here are simply sleeping—
Some chose this journey, stepped with conscious care.

The dolente city's spires pierce the sky,
Its foundations rest on bones of yesterday.
I stand before its gates and wonder why
Its siren call I cannot keep at bay.

Dante knew this passage all too well,
The descent through circles ever tightening.
What wisdom waits within this citadel?
What truths hide in its darkness, frightening?

Perhaps we need these journeys to the deep,
To touch the pain that makes us truly whole.
For only after we have learned to weep,
Can joy find proper purchase in the soul.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Born in the famine struck Africa'

responses.text:
Born in the famine struck Africa,
Where dust claims more territory than rain.
I learned to swallow my hunger
Before I learned to speak.

My mother's lullabies were prayers
For clouds to break their silence.
Her hands, maps of drought lines,
Cradled my fragile body like the last seed.

The world watched through camera lenses,
Capturing our hollow cheeks for distant screens.
They called us statistics, called us tragedy,
But never called us by our names.

Yet from this parched earth,
I grew like the baobab—
Roots deep in ancestral wisdom,
Branches reaching toward possibility.

For we are more than our suffering:
We are storytellers, inventors, dreamers.
In the land where life began,
We continue to begin again.

FAMINE'S CHILD

Born in the famine struck Africa,
I emerged between dust and desperation,
A first breath drawn in a place
Where breath itself was luxury.

The sun, once worshipped as life-giver,
Became our merciless overseer.
Riverbeds cracked like ancient scrolls,
Their messages of thirst unheeded.

My playground: the skeletal remains
Of what once was verdant land.
My toys: empty cans from foreign aid,
Painted with logos of distant compassion.

They photographed my distended belly,
Captured my eyes too large for my face.
I became the poster child
For a world's momentary guilt.

Yet in this crucible of hunger,
I discovered the taste of resilience—
Sweeter than any promised salvation,
Stronger than the chains of pity.

DROUGHT INHERITANCE

Born in the famine struck Africa,
I inherited the language of thirst.
My first memories: the hollow drum
Of my mother's empty stomach against my ear.

The elders spoke of green seasons past,
Of harvests abundant before the sky forgot us.
Their words fell like precious water drops
Into the parched soil of my imagination.

We measured wealth in raindrops,
In grains of millet saved for tomorrow.
Our currency: the strength to stand
When standing meant defying gravity.

At night, I dreamed of oceans
I had never seen but somehow knew—
Vast waters that existed somewhere
Beyond our horizon of scarcity.

Now I carry this contradiction:
A child of drought who overflows with stories,
A descendant of hunger who feasts on hope,
A seed that bloomed despite the barren ground.

THE UNWELCOME BIRTH

Born in the famine struck Africa,
Another mouth to feed in the season of none.
My arrival: a miracle and burden both,
A testament to life's stubborn persistence.

The village women whispered
That I came during the worst moon,
When even the vultures flew elsewhere,
Unable to find sustenance in our suffering.

My father walked three days to find water,
Returned with barely enough to wet my lips.
He named me Baraka—blessing—
A defiant hope against evidence.

I learned early the geometry of survival:
How to fold myself small against hunger pangs,
How to stretch a single meal across days,
How to stand tall when weakness beckoned.

Decades later, in lands of plenty,
I still clean my plate completely,
Still wake at the sound of rainfall,
Still carry the weight of those who didn't survive.

HUNGER'S BIRTHRIGHT

Born in the famine struck Africa,
Where death was the midwife
And survival, the first gift
No one thought I'd receive.

The news never mentioned our names—
Only numbers rising like heat waves
From the cracked earth that once
Nurtured generations before mine.

My childhood playmates:
The shadows of birds circling overhead,
Patient observers of our slow surrender,
Waiting for the inevitable surrender.

But surrender never came to our village.
We drank dew from leaves before dawn,
Chewed on roots bitter with resilience,
Told stories that fed our souls when nothing fed our bodies.

Now I stand between worlds,
A translator of hunger and abundance,
A witness to both human cruelty
And the stubborn miracle of human kindness.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Born in the famine struck Africa'

responses.text:

I learned early the mathematics of survival:

Born in the famine struck Africa
I emerged from the womb already knowing thirst

Through empty granaries, the soft moans

The earth cracked like my father's hands
Both once fertile, now bearing nothing
But memories of abundance.
I learned to read clouds before books,
To pray for gray bellies heavy with rain.

My playground was the shadow
Of an ancient baobab that remembered
Greener times, its roots reaching
Deeper than our collective pain.
It taught me persistence.

They say hardship shapes you—
Mine carved me hollow like a drum.
Now when I speak, I resonate
With voices of those who didn't survive.
I am their echo, their continuation,

Born in the famine struck Africa
Where vultures circle patient as prayer
I came into this world already owing a debt

My first toys were pebbles and bones
Polished by the same relentless sun
That dried our rivers to veins of sand.

Of those seeking water, seeking life.

The foreign cameras captured our ribs
But missed our dignity, the way we shared
The last grain, how we held each other
Through nights when hunger clawed
Like animals inside our hollow spaces.

I carry this birthright now across oceans—
Not just the memory of lack
But the alchemy of survival,
The knowledge that even in barren soil
Something fierce and beautiful can grow.

Born in the famine struck Africa
I entered a world of contradictions:
A continent rich with resources
Yet children with matchstick limbs,

My cradle was my mother's arms
Thin but strong as baobab branches.
She hummed songs of ancestors
Who survived worse than this,
Their resilience flowing in my veins
Before mother's milk ever could.

We measured wealth differently—
By smiles shared around empty pots,

From dust and desperation,

Now I stand, testament to survival,
Voice shaped by absence, presence

INHERITANCE

DROUGHT'S DAUGHTER

Born in the famine struck Africa,

before I learned to speak.

thin but steady as acacia branches.

the way stars fed our imagination
when nothing fed our bodies.

I grew alongside questions:

while we measure dust in cups?

Years later, crossing oceans,
I carry drought within me—
a desert stretched across my memory.

In lands of abundance, I still
save crusts, store water,

But also: I know joy's true weight,
can find feast in simple meals,
and recognize the rich who starve
amid their plenty.

to transform scarcity

THE UNWRITTEN HISTORY

Born in the famine struck Africa,

responses.text:

Birthright

My first breath drawn in a place

In shallow graves beside their young.

The aid trucks come like modern chariots,

They photograph our hollow cheeks,
Capture our dignity in black and white.

I carry my heritage in my bones,

Born in the famine struck Africa,

The Unbroken

Born in the famine struck Africa,

My father walked for days

The world knows us by our ribs,

I grew between drought and promise,

Born in famine struck Africa,

Famine's Daughter

Born in the famine struck Africa,

My childhood games were searching for roots,

Who would eventually tire and leave.

Yet there was beauty in our barren lands—
In the way the community shared one cup of maize,
In how grandmothers told stories that fed our minds
When nothing could feed our bodies.

I learned that hunger is a teacher
Whose lessons are carved into memory.
Born in famine struck Africa,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Homer poured, in thousand wrote.'

responses.text:
Epic Inheritance

Homer poured, in thousand wrote,
Ancient tales from distant shores.
Odysseus and Achilles float
Through time on literary oars.

Words cascading like Aegean waves,
Blind bard's vision clear as light.
Heroes' journeys, fallen braves,
Echoing through endless night.

In amphoras of meter sealed,
Wine of wisdom, aged with care.
Human truths forever revealed
In verses flowing everywhere.

From one mouth to countless minds,
Stories ripple, never cease.
Across millennia, one finds
The poet's soul in masterpiece.

Homer poured, in thousand wrote,
And still we drink those words today.
On timeless currents, still we float,
Guided by his ancient way.

Poetic Legacy

Homer poured, in thousand wrote,
The nectar of his blinded sight.
Across the sea of time, his boat
Sails on through day and night.

A single voice that multiplied,
Like drops of rain on barren soil.
The seeds of verse that never died,
But flourished through the toil.

From Ilium's walls to Ithaca's shore,
His words like rivers flowed.
Each generation adding more,
To what the master showed.

The wine of epic, sweet and strong,
Decanted through the years.
A chorus joined his single song,
Through laughter, rage, and tears.

So when we write, remember well,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'An account of books 16-19 of the Iliad by Homer.'

responses.text:
The Wrath of Achilles

Between these pages, gods and mortals clash,
As Patroclus dons Achilles' gleaming mail.
Across the battlefield, a fateful dash,
Where Hector's spear ensures his quest will fail.

Book sixteen: a friend in borrowed armor falls,
Seventeen: for his corpse, they fiercely fight.
Eighteen: divine-forged weapons answer calls,
Nineteen: grief transforms to vengeful might.

The son of Peleus weeps beside the shore,
While silver-footed Thetis mourns his pain.
A shield is forged with scenes of peace and war,
As Troy awaits the fury of his reign.

The drums of battle echo through the age,
Immortal lines on Homer's timeless page.

ECHOES OF BRONZE

Patroclus rises, borrowed glory his shroud,
Achilles' armor gleaming false promise.
Trojans retreat before this specter proud,
Until great Hector claims his blood as homage.

Bodies sprawl like fallen autumn leaves,
Over corpses, chariots and spears clash wild.
Zeus watches, as his golden scale weaves
Fate's decree—a warrior reconciled.

Thetis descends to Hephaestus' flame,
Begging godly craft for mortal revenge.
A shield emerges, cosmos its frame,
While Achilles' wrath finds new edge.

Briseis returned, the assembly convened,
Oaths sworn upon the hollow ships' decks.
Across these books, mortality's meaning gleaned:
Glory's brief flame before darkness collects.

The Turning Tide

In sixteen, brave Patroclus takes the field,
Draped in armor not his own to claim.
He pushes back the Trojans, makes them yield,
Until Apollo strikes and Hector aims.

Seventeen sees battle for the fallen friend,
Ajax and Menelaus stand their ground.
As messages of death to Achilles wend,
And grief's dark clouds begin to gather round.

In eighteen, divine hands craft new shield,
As Thetis bears her son's lament to gods.
Hephaestus works the metal, fate is sealed,
The cosmos rendered on its face—how odd!

Nineteen brings reconciliation's breath,
Achilles and Agamemnon end their strife.
The hero rises, hungry now for death—
His own foretold, yet choosing glory's life.

ILIAD'S HEART

When Patroclus falls beneath Trojan sky,
The earth itself trembles with coming doom.
Like autumn leaves, warriors multiply,
Their bodies scattered—nature's crimson bloom.

Apollo's hand guides Hector's fatal thrust,
While over corpses, Greeks and Trojans war.
Ajax stands firm—in him, the Achaeans trust,
As battle rages on the blood-soaked shore.

From depths of sea, a mother's grief ascends,
To forge new armor in immortal flame.
Upon a shield, the cosmos never ends—
Life's tapestry beyond mere mortal fame.

Achilles rises from his bitter rest,
Briseis returned, his honor now restored.
The armies gather for war's final test,
As Troy awaits the vengeance long ignored.

Bronze Songs of Fate

Sixteen through nineteen, the epic unfolds—
Patroclus dons the armor not his own,
Driving Trojans back from ships' dark holds,
Until by Hector's spear he's overthrown.

Around his body swirls the brutal dance,
Menelaus, Ajax, fighting through the throng.
While Antilochus runs with grievous glance,
To tell Achilles everything gone wrong.

The silver-footed goddess hears the cry,
Descending to the craftsman's fiery den.
A shield is born beneath immortal eye,
With scenes of peace amidst the wars of men.

The assembly called, Achilles' wrath now turned
From Agamemnon toward the Trojan force.
Briseis weeps for what cannot return—
As fate drives heroes on their deadly course.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'An account of books 16-19 of the Iliad by Homer.'

responses.text:
ACHILLES' WRATH

Patroclus falls beneath the Trojan spear,
His blood now mingles with the dusty plain.
Achilles weeps, consumed by grief severe,
As news arrives of his dear friend now slain.

The armor stripped from brave Patroclus' form
Becomes the prize of Hector's battle-might.
While Greeks retreat before the Trojan storm,
And ships burn bright against the fading light.

New armor forged by Hephaestus' hand,
A shield that bears the cosmos in its face.
Achilles rises, terrible and grand,
His rage eclipsing mercy, love, and grace.

The river chokes with bodies of the dead,
As vengeance drives the swift-foot hero on.
No peace for Hector, doom hangs o'er his head,
The light of Troy will fade before the dawn.

THE MIDDLE CHAPTERS

Where bronze meets flesh and gods walk among men,
Patroclus dons Achilles' shining plate.
The fool's disguise works well—until then—
When Hector's spear delivers certain fate.

Apollo's hand, invisible but true,
Disarms the Greek who overreached his bounds.
The armor lost, the hero broken through,
As Trojan triumph over grief resounds.

Then blackest news to swift Achilles comes;
His dearest friend lies cold upon the field.
While mothers weep and beat their breasts like drums,
The son of Peleus refuses to yield.

A mother's gift: divine-wrought arms anew,
Forged in the depths where mortals cannot tread.
Revenge now burns his heart completely through—
No rest for him till Hector's soul has fled.

IMMORTAL VERSES

Sixteen through nineteen, middle of the tale,
Where glory meets its cost in crimson tide.
Patroclus rises, only then to fail,
As Zeus decrees and fate cannot be denied.

The battle rages 'round the fallen Greek,
Like wolves and jackals fighting for the slain.
While Hector claims the armor as his prize,
Achilles' wrath builds like a hurricane.

The silver-footed Thetis seeks a gift,
From lame Hephaestus, master of the forge.
A shield of wonder, armor made to lift
A hero to his vengeance, gorge for gorge.

The cosmos dances on the shield's broad face—
The stars, the seas, the cities filled with life.
While in Achilles' heart, an empty space
Where once lived joy, now filled with coming strife.

THE PRICE OF PRIDE

Patroclus, fool of kindness, dons the helm
Of great Achilles, hoping Greeks to save.
He pushes back the Trojans from their realm,
But finds himself too soon within the grave.

The corpse contested like a scrap of land,
As Ajax stands defiant, spear in hand.
While Hector gloats in armor not his own,
Achilles wails, a heart-destroying moan.

A mother's love brings gifts of godly make,
As Thetis weeps for what her son must bear.
The shield a universe, for vengeance' sake,
While Troy awaits with hope mixed with despair.

The river soon will flow with mortal blood,
As grief transforms to violence unrestrained.
No prayer or plea can stop the coming flood—
The path to Hades thoroughly ordained.

ECHOES OF BRONZE

Between the ships and walls, where heroes fall,
Patroclus surges forth in borrowed might.
His final charge, his last heroic call,
Before Apollo dims his mortal light.

The armor stripped, the body left behind,
As vultures circle, waiting for their share.
The news flies swift as thought upon the wind,
To break Achilles' heart beyond repair.

The sea-nymph rises from her watery home,
To comfort son and promise godly steel.
While in the forge, where flame and metal roam,
The lame god works wonders none can steal.

Upon the shield, life dances endlessly—
The weddings, wars, and harvests of mankind.
While in the camp, Achilles restlessly
Awaits the dawn, revenge upon his mind.
